whole time intervalexpressing quantified temporal tenses"once" contrasted with "only once" quantified temporal tensescaveat on implication of It is necessary to be careful with sentences like and , where a quantified tense appears without an interval. What really says is that during an interval of unspecified size, at least part of which was set in the past, the event of my going to the market happened twice. The example says nothing about what happened outside that vague time interval. This is often less than we mean. If we want to nail down that I went to the market once and only once, we can use the cmavo
ze'e which represents the
whole time interval: conceptually, an interval which stretches from time's beginning to its end:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ze'e paroi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [whole interval] [once] go-to the market.

section.para: Since specifying no ZEhA leaves the interval vague, might in appropriate context mean the same as after all – but allows us to be specific when specificity is necessary.

PU selma'o ze'ecameaning of ze'ebameaning of ze'epumeaning of ze'eeffect on following PU direction temporal directionexception in meaning when following ze'e A PU cmavo following ze'e has a slightly different meaning from one that follows another ZEhA cmavo. The compound cmavo
ze'epu signifies the interval stretching from the infinite past to the reference point (wherever the imaginary journey has taken you);
ze'eba is the interval stretching from the reference point to the infinite future. The remaining form,
ze'eca, makes specific the
whole of time interpretation just given. These compound forms make it possible to assert that something has never happened without asserting that it never will.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ze'epu noroi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [whole interval] [past] [never] go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I have never gone to the market.

section.para: says nothing about whether I might go in future.

quantified space The space equivalent of ze'e is
ve'e, and it can be used in the same way with a quantified space tense: see
for an explanation of space interval modifiers.

section.title: Event contours: ZAhO and re'u
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

aspectnatural languages compared with respect to aspectexpressing resumptive event contour pausative event contour achievative event contour superfective event contour completitive event contour cessitive event contour initiative event contour perfective event contour continuitive event contour inchoative event contour The cmavo of selma'o ZAhO express the Lojban version of what is traditionally called aspect. This is not a notion well expressed by English tenses, but many languages (including Chinese and Russian among Lojban's six source languages) consider it more important than the specification of mere position in time.

event contoursorder with respect to TAhE and ROI event contourssyntax of eventsconsidered as a process event contoursdefinition The event contours of selma'o ZAhO, with their bizarre keywords, represent the natural portions of an event considered as a process, an occurrence with an internal structure including a beginning, a middle, and an end. Since the keywords are scarcely self-explanatory, each ZAhO will be explained in detail here. Note that from the viewpoint of Lojban syntax, ZAhOs are interval modifiers like TAhEs or ROI compounds; if both are found in a single tense, the TAhE/ROI comes first and the ZAhO afterward. The imaginary journey described by other tense cmavo moves us to the portion of the event-as-process which the ZAhO specifies.

event contoursas characteristic portions of events speaker-relative viewpointcontrasted with event-relative viewpoint event-relative viewpointcontrasted with speaker-relative viewpoint tensesviewpoint of PU contrasted with viewpoint of ZAhO PU tensescontrasted with ZAhO tenses in viewpoint event contoursas timeless in perspective It is important to understand that ZAhO cmavo, unlike the other tense cmavo, specify characteristic portions of the event, and are seen from an essentially timeless perspective. The beginning of an event is the same whether the event is in the speaker's present, past, or future. It is especially important not to confuse the speaker-relative viewpoint of the PU tenses with the event-relative viewpoint of the ZAhO tenses.

ca'oderivation of word ba'oderivation of word pu'oderivation of word The cmavo pu'o, ca'o, and ba'o (etymologically derived from the PU cmavo) refer to an event that has not yet begun, that is in progress, or that has ended, respectively:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu'o damba
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [inchoative] fight.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I'm on the verge of fighting.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la stiv. ca'o bacru
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Steve [continuitive] utters.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Steve continues to talk.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba ba'o cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The child [perfective] walks-on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The child is finished walking on the ice.

section.para:
tense directioncontrasted with event contours in implication of extent event contourscontrasted with tense direction in implication of extent event contoursimplications on scope of event event contoursperfective event contourscontinuitive event contoursinchoative As discussed in , the simple PU cmavo make no assumptions about whether the scope of a past, present, or future event extends into one of the other tenses as well.
through illustrate that these ZAhO cmavo do make such assumptions possible: the event in 10.1 has not yet begun, definitively; likewise, the event in 10.3 is definitely over.

ba'oas futureward of event pu'oas pastward of event ba'oexplanation of derivation pu'oexplanation of derivation Note that in and , pu'o and ba'o may appear to be reversed: pu'o, although etymologically connected with pu, is referring to a future event; whereas
ba'o, connected with ba, is referring to a past event. This is the natural result of the event-centered view of ZAhO cmavo. The inchoative, or
pu'o, part of an event, is in the pastward portion of that event, when seen from the perspective of the event itself. It is only by inference that we suppose that
refers to the speaker's future: in fact, no PU tense is given, so the inchoative part of the event need not be coincident with the speaker's present: pu'o is not necessarily, though in fact often is, the same as ca pu'o.

event contourscessative event contoursinitiative event contoursdivision of the event into event contourspoints associated with The cmavo in through refer to spans of time. There are also two points of time that can be usefully associated with an event: the beginning, marked by co'a, and the end, marked by co'u. Specifically, co'a marks the boundary between the pu'o and ca'o parts of an event, and co'u marks the boundary between the ca'o and ba'o parts:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba co'a citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [future] [initiative] eat my meal.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I will begin to eat my meal.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu co'u citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [cessitive] eat my meal.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I ceased eating my meal.

section.para: Compare with:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba di'i co'a bajra
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [future] [regularly] [initiative] run.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I will regularly begin to run.

section.para: which illustrates the combination of a TAhE with a ZAhO.

event contourscompletitive stopcontrasted with finish finishcontrasted with stop actual stopcontrasted with natural end natural endcontrasted with actual stop A process can have two end points, one reflecting the natural end (when the process is complete) and the other reflecting the
actual stopping point (whether complete or not). may be contrasted with:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu mo'u citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [completitive] eat my meal.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I finished eating my meal.

section.para:
In , the meal has reached its natural end; in
, the meal has merely ceased, without necessarily reaching its natural end.

event contoursresumptive event contourspausative event contoursresumption event contoursinterruption begincontrasted with resume resumecontrasted with begin pausecontrasted with stop stopcontrasted with pause A process such as eating a meal does not necessarily proceed uninterrupted. If it is interrupted, there are two more relevant point events: the point just before the interruption, marked by de'a, and the point just after the interruption, marked by
di'a. Some examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu de'a citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [pausative] eat my meal.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I stopped eating my meal (with the intention of resuming).

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba di'a citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [future] [resumptive] eat my meal.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I will resume eating my meal.

section.para:
event contourssuperfective natural endcontinuing beyond In addition, it is possible for a process to continue beyond its natural end. The span of time between the natural and the actual end points is represented by
za'o:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ctuca pu za'o ciksi le cmaci seldanfu le tadgri
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The teacher [past] [superfective] explained the mathematics problem to the student-group.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The teacher kept on explaining the mathematics problem to the class too long.

section.para: That is, the teacher went on explaining after the class already understood the problem.
pointevent considered as event contoursachievative An entire event can be treated as a single moment using the cmavo co'i:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. pu co'i catra la djim
interlinear-gloss.gloss: John [past] [achievative] kills Jim.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: John was at the point in time where he killed Jim.

section.para: cycles ordinal tense Finally, since an activity is cyclical, an individual cycle can be referred to using a number followed by re'u, which is the other cmavo of selma'o ROI:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pare'u klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [first time] go-to the store.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go to the store for the first time (within a vague interval).

section.para: Note the difference between:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pare'u paroi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [first time] [one time] go-to the store.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: For the first time, I go to the store once.

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi paroi pare'u klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [one time] [first time] go-to the store.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: There is one occasion on which I go to the store for the first time.

section.title: Space interval modifiers: FEhE
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

tenseorder of spatial interval modifiers in spatial interval modifiersorder in tense spatial intervalsexpressing degree of continuity over space intervalscompared with time intervals in continuity Like time intervals, space intervals can also be continuous, discontinuous, or repetitive. Rather than having a whole separate set of selma'o for space interval properties, we instead prefix the flag
fe'e to the cmavo used for time interval properties. A space interval property would be placed just after the space interval size and/or dimensionality cmavo:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ko vi'i fe'e di'i sombo le gurni
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You-imperative [1-dimensional] [space:] [regularly] sow the grain.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Sow the grain in a line and evenly!

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi fe'e ciroi tervecnu lo selsalta
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [space:] [three places] buy those-which-are salad-ingredients.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I buy salad ingredients in three locations.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ze'e roroi ve'e fe'e roroi ku li re su'i re du li vo
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [whole time] [all times] [whole space] [space:] [all places] The-number 2 + 2 = the-number 4.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Always and everywhere, two plus two is four.

section.para: As shown in , when a tense comes first in a bridi, rather than in its normal position before the selbri (in this case du), it is emphasized.

ZAhO selma'o spatial contoursexpressing The fe'e marker can also be used for the same purpose before members of ZAhO. (The cmavo be'a belongs to selma'o FAhA; it is the space direction meaning
north of.)

interlinear-gloss.jbo: tu ve'abe'a fe'e co'a rokci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That-yonder [medium space interval - north] [space] [initiative] is-a-rock.
That is the beginning of a rock extending to my north.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is the south face of a rock.

section.para:
event contourstemporal contrasted with spatial spatial contourscontrasted with temporal event contours beginning pointspatial Here the notion of a beginning point represented by the cmavo
co'a is transferred from beginning in time to beginning in space under the influence of the fe'e flag. Space is not inherently oriented, unlike time, which flows from past to future: therefore, some indication of orientation is necessary, and the ve'abe'a provides an orientation in which the south face is the
beginning and the north face is the end, since the rock extends from south (near me) to north (away from me).

FAhA selma'ouse in specifying space/time mapping direction space/time metaphorexpressing direction mapping for spaceas time-based metaphor timeas space-based metaphor Many natural languages represent time by a space-based metaphor: in English, what is past is said to be behind us. In other languages, the metaphor is reversed. Here, Lojban is representing space (or space interval modifiers) by a time-based metaphor: the choice of a FAhA cmavo following a VEhA cmavo indicates which direction is mapped onto the future. (The choice of future rather than past is arbitrary, but convenient for English-speakers.)

fe'eeffect of TAhE/ROI with ZAhO on ZAhO selma'oeffect on fe'e flag for TAhE and ROI ROI selma'oeffect of ZAhO on fe'e flag TAhE selma'oeffect of ZAhO on fe'e flag If both a TAhE (or ROI) and a ZAhO are present as space interval modifiers, the fe'e flag must be prefixed to each.

section.title: Tenses as sumti tcita
section.para: argument tagsbased on tenses (see also sumti tcita) sumti tcitabased on tenses temporal informationadding to a sentence with tense sumti tcita spatial informationadding to a sentence with tense sumti tcita tensesuse as sumti tcita So far, we have seen tenses only just before the selbri, or (equivalently in meaning) floating about the bridi with ku. There is another major use for tenses in Lojban: as sumti tcita, or argument tags. A tense may be used to add spatial or temporal information to a bridi as, in effect, an additional place:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci ca le nu do klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [present] the event-of you go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go to the market when you go to the house.

section.para: sumti tcitabased on tense direction tense directionas sumti tcita cameaning as a sumti tcita Here ca does not appear before the selbri, nor with ku; instead, it governs the following sumti, the le nu construct. What asserts is that the action of the main bridi is happening at the same time as the event mentioned by that sumti. So ca, which means now when used with a selbri, means simultaneously-with when used with a sumti. Consider another example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci pu le nu do pu klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [past] the event-of you [past] go-to the house.

section.para: The second pu is simply the past tense marker for the event of your going to the house, and says that this event is in the speaker's past. How are we to understand the first pu, the sumti tcita?

imaginary journeystarting at a different point imaginary journeystarting point All of our imaginary journeys so far have started at the speaker's location in space and time. Now we are specifying an imaginary journey that starts at a different location, namely at the event of your going to the house. then says that my going to the market is in the past, relative not to the speaker's present moment, but instead relative to the moment when you went to the house. can therefore be translated:

blockquote.para: I had gone to the market before you went to the house.

section.para: sumti tcitabased on tense distance tense distanceas sumti tcita spatial tensesas sumti tcita (Other translations are possible, depending on the ever-present context.) Spatial direction and distance sumti tcita are exactly analogous:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu cu citka le cirla vi le panka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The rat eats the cheese [short distance] the park.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The rat eats the cheese near the park.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu cu citka le cirla vi le vu panka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The rat eats the cheese [short distance] the [long distance] park
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The rat eats the cheese near the faraway park.

indexterm.primary: far away from the nearby park

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu cu citka le cirla vu le vi panka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The rat eats the cheese [long distance] the [short distance] park
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The rat eats the cheese far away from the nearby park.

section.para:
sumti tcita based on event contoursrelation of main bridi to sumti process in sumti tcitaevent contours contrasted with direction/distance as basis for tense direction/distance as sumti tcitacontrasted with event contours event contours as sumti tcitacontrasted with direction and distance ZAhO selma'o sumti tcitabased on spatial contours spatial contoursas sumti tcita sumti tcitabased on event contours event contoursas sumti tcita The event contours of selma'o ZAhO (and their space equivalents, prefixed with
fe'e) are also useful as sumti tcita. The interpretation of ZAhO tcita differs from that of FAhA, VA, PU, and ZI tcita, however. The event described in the sumti is viewed as a process, and the action of the main bridi occurs at the phase of the process which the ZAhO specifies, or at least some part of that phase. The action of the main bridi itself is seen as a point event, so that there is no issue about which phase of the main bridi is intended. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi morsi ba'o le nu mi jmive
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-dead [perfective] the event-of I live.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I die in the aftermath of my living.

section.para: Here the (point-)event of my being dead is the portion of my living-process which occurs after the process is complete. Contrast with:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi morsi ba le nu mi jmive
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-dead [future] the event-of I live.

section.para: As explained in , does not exclude the possibility that I died before I ceased to live!
Likewise, we might say:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci pu'o le nu mi citka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the store [inchoative] the event-of I eat

section.para: which indicates that before my eating begins, I go to the store, whereas

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci ba'o le nu mi citka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the store [perfective] the event-of I eat

section.para: would indicate that I go to the store after I am finished eating.
Here is an example which mixes temporal ZAhO (as a tense) and spatial ZAhO (as a sumti tcita):

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le bloti pu za'o xelklama fe'e ba'o le lalxu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The boat [past] [superfective] is-a-transport-mechanism [space] [perfective] the lake.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The boat sailed for too long and beyond the lake.

section.para: Probably it sailed up onto the dock. One point of clarification: although xelklama appears to mean simply is-a-mode-of-transport, it does not – the bridi of has four omitted arguments, and thus has the (physical) journey which goes on too long as part of its meaning.

sumti tcita based on quantified tenses quantified tensesas sumti tcita sumti tcita based on interval properties interval propertiesmeaning as sumti tcita sumti tcita based on interval continuousness interval continuousnessmeaning as sumti tcita sumti tcita based on dimension dimensionmeaning as sumti tcita sumti tcita based on interval size interval sizemeaning as sumti tcita The remaining tense cmavo, which have to do with interval size, dimension, and continuousness (or lack thereof) are interpreted to let the sumti specify the particular interval over which the main bridi operates:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci reroi le ca djedi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [twice] the [present] day.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go/went/will go to the market twice today.

section.para: tense inside sumticontrasted with tense as sumti tcita tense as sumti tcitacontrasted with tense inside sumti Be careful not to confuse a tense used as a sumti tcita with a tense used within a seltcita sumti:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: loi snime cu carvi ze'u le ca dunra
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Some-of-the-mass-of snow rains [long time interval] the [present] winter.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Snow falls during this winter.

section.para: claims that the interval specified by this winter is long, as events of snowfall go, whereas

interlinear-gloss.jbo: loi snime cu carvi ca le ze'u dunra
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Some-of-the-mass-of snow rains [present] the [long time] winter.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Snow falls in the long winter.

section.para: claims that during some part of the winter, which is long as winters go, snow falls.

section.title: Sticky and multiple tenses: KI
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

imaginary journey originwith sticky tenses sticky tenseseffect on future tense meaning sticky tensesdefinition tensescope of So far we have only considered tenses in isolated bridi. Lojban provides several ways for a tense to continue in effect over more than a single bridi. This property is known as stickiness: the tense gets stuck and remains in effect until explicitly unstuck. In the metaphor of the imaginary journey, the place and time set by a sticky tense may be thought of as a campsite or way-station: it provides a permanent origin with respect to which other tenses are understood. Later imaginary journeys start from that point rather than from the speaker.
To make a tense sticky, suffix ki to it:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi puki klama le zarci .i le nanmu cu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [sticky] go-to the market. The man bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I went to the market. The man bit the dog.

section.para: Here the use of puki rather than just pu ensures that the tense will affect the next sentence as well. Otherwise, since the second sentence is tenseless, there would be no way of determining its tense; the event of the second sentence might happen before, after, or simultaneously with that of the first sentence.
(The last statement does not apply when the two sentences form part of a narrative. See for an explanation of story time, which employs a different set of conventions.)
What if the second sentence has a tense anyway?

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi puki klama le zarci .i le nanmu pu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [sticky] go-to the market. The man [past] bites the dog.

section.para: Here the second pu does not replace the sticky tense, but adds to it, in the sense that the starting point of its imaginary journey is taken to be the previously set sticky time. So the translation of is:

example.para: I went to the market. The man had earlier bitten the dog.

section.para: compound tensecompared with tense in scope of sticky tense tense in scope of sticky tensecompared with compound tense and it is equivalent in meaning (when considered in isolation from any other sentences) to:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu klama le zarci .i le nanmu pupu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] go-to the market. The man [past] [past] bites the dog.

section.para: compound tensecompared with multiple tenses in sentence tensesmultiple in sentence compared with compound tense tensesmultiple in sentence The point has not been discussed so far, but it is perfectly grammatical to have more than one tense construct in a sentence:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: puku mi ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [past] I [future] go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Earlier, I was going to go to the market.

section.para: Here there are two tenses in the same bridi, the first floating free and specified by puku, the second in the usual place and specified by ba. They are considered cumulative in the same way as the two tenses in separate sentences of . is therefore equivalent in meaning, except for emphasis, to:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi puba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [future] go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I was going to go to the market.

section.para: multiple tenseseffect of order in sentence Compare and , which have a different meaning from and :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba klama le zarci puku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [future] go-to the market [past].
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I will have gone to the market earlier.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bapu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [future] [past] go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I will have gone to the market.

section.para: So when multiple tense constructs in a single bridi are involved, order counts – the tenses cannot be shifted around as freely as if there were only one tense to worry about.

sticky tensesfrom part of a multiple tense But why bother to allow multiple tense constructs at all? They specify separate portions of the imaginary journey, and can be useful in order to make part of a tense sticky. Consider , which adds a second bridi and a ki to :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pukiku mi ba klama le zarci .i le nanmu cu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [past] [sticky] I [future] go-to the market. The man bites the dog.

section.para: What is the implied tense of the second sentence? Not puba, but only pu, since only pu was made sticky with ki. So the translation is:

blockquote.para: I was going to go to the market. The man bit the dog.

section.para: sumti with tenseeffect of main bridi tense on embedded bridi tenseseffect of main bridi tense on tense on main bridieffect on embedded sumti with tenses tense on main bridieffect on embedded bridi tenses tenseon embedded bridi Lojban has several ways of embedding a bridi within another bridi: descriptions, abstractors, relative clauses. (Technically, descriptions contain selbri rather than bridi.) Any of the selbri of these subordinate bridi may have tenses attached. These tenses are interpreted relative to the tense of the main bridi:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu klama le ba'o zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] go-to the [perfective] market
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I went to the former market.

section.para:
The significance of the ba'o in is that the speaker's destination is described as being in the aftermath of being a market; that is, it is a market no longer. In particular, the time at which it was no longer a market is in the speaker's past, because the
ba'o is interpreted relative to the pu tense of the main bridi.
Here is an example involving an abstraction bridi:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ca jinvi le du'u mi ba morsi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I now opine the fact-that I will-be dead.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I now believe that I will be dead.

section.para: Here the event of being dead is said to be in the future with respect to the opinion, which is in the present.

kiwith no tense sticky tensescanceling ki may also be used as a tense by itself. This cancels all stickiness and returns the bridi and all following bridi to the speaker's location in both space and time.

tensehandling multiple episodes tensesubscripting subscriptsfor sticky tense In complex descriptions, multiple tenses may be saved and then used by adding a subscript to
ki. A time made sticky with kixipa (ki-sub-1) can be returned to by specifying kixipa as a tense by itself. In the case of written expression, the writer's here-and-now is often different from the reader's, and a pair of subscripted ki tenses could be used to distinguish the two.

section.title: Story time
section.para: storiesflow of time in story timerationale for story timedefinition Making strict use of the conventions explained in would be intolerably awkward when a story is being told. The time at which a story is told by the narrator is usually unimportant to the story. What matters is the flow of time within the story itself. The term story in this section refers to any series of statements related in more-or-less time-sequential order, not just a fictional one.

story timetenseless sentences in tenseless sentences in story time story timeas a convention for inferring tense Lojban speakers use a different set of conventions, commonly called story time, for inferring tense within a story. It is presumed that the event described by each sentence takes place some time more or less after the previous ones. Therefore, tenseless sentences are implicitly tensed as
what happens next. In particular, any sticky time setting is advanced by each sentence.
The following mini-story illustrates the important features of story time. A sentence-by-sentence explication follows:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: puzuki ku ne'iki le kevna le ninmu goi ko'a zutse le rokci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [past] [long] [sticky] [,] [inside] [sticky] the cave, the woman defined-as she-1 sat-on the rock
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Long ago, in a cave, a woman sat on a rock.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i ko'a citka loi kanba rectu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: She-1 [tenseless] eat some-of-the-mass-of goat flesh.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: She was eating goat's meat.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i ko'a pu jukpa ri le mudyfagri
interlinear-gloss.gloss: She [past] cook the-last-mentioned by-method the wood-fire.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: She had cooked the meat over a wood fire.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i lei rectu cu zanglare
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-mass-of flesh is-(favorable)-warm.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The meat was pleasantly warm.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i le labno goi ko'e bazaki nenri klama le kevna
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The wolf defined-as it-2 [future] [medium] [sticky] within-came to-the cave.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: A while later, a wolf came into the cave.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i ko'e lebna lei rectu ko'a
interlinear-gloss.gloss: It-2 [tenseless] takes the-mass-of flesh from-her-1.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: It took the meat from her.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i ko'e bartu klama
interlinear-gloss.gloss: It-2 out ran
interlinear-gloss.natlang: It ran out.

section.para:
story tenseLojban convention contrasted with English convention sets both the time (long ago) and the place (in a cave) using
ki, just like the sentence sequences in . No further space cmavo are used in the rest of the story, so the place is assumed to remain unchanged. The English translation of is marked for past tense also, as the conventions of English storytelling require: consequently, all other English translation sentences are also in the past tense. (We don't notice how strange this is; even stories about the future are written in past tense!) This conventional use of past tense is not used in Lojban narratives.
has an explicit tense. This is taken relative to the latest setting of the sticky time; therefore, the event of happens before that of . It cannot be determined if happens before or after .
is again tenseless. Story time was not changed by the flashback in , so happens after .
and are again tenseless, and so happen after . (Story time is changed.)
So the overall order is - - - - (medium interval) - - - . It is also possible that happens before .

story timewith no initial sticky time If no sticky time (or space) is set initially, the story is set at an unspecified time (or space): the effect is like that of choosing an arbitrary reference point and making it sticky. This style is common in stories that are jokes. The same convention may be used if the context specifies the sticky time sufficiently.

section.title: Tenses in subordinate bridi
section.para: subordinate clausestense usage rules in English English has a set of rules, formally known as sequence of tense rules, for determining what tense should be used in a subordinate clause, depending on the tense used in the main sentence. Here are some examples:

example.para: John says that George is going to the market.
John says that George went to the market.
John said that George went to the market.
John said that George had gone to the market.

section.para: In and , the tense of the main sentence is the present: says. If George goes when John speaks, we get the present tense is going ( goes would be unidiomatic); if George goes before John speaks, we get the past tense went. But if the tense of the main sentence is the past, with said, then the tense required in the subordinate clause is different. If George goes when John speaks, we get the past tense went; if George goes before John speaks, we get the past-perfect tense had gone.

subordinate clause tenseeffect of main bridi tense on subordinate clause tenseLojban compared with Esperanto subordinate clause tenseLojban compared with Russian subordinate clause tenseLojban contrasted with English sequence of tense rulesLojban contrasted with English Lojban, like Russian and Esperanto, uses a different convention. A tense in a subordinate bridi is understood to be relative to the tense already set in the main bridi. Thus through can be expressed in Lojban respectively thus:

indexterm.primary: John says that George goes to market

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. ca cusku le se du'u la djordj. ca klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: John [present] says the statement-that George [present] goes-to the market.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. ca cusku le se du'u la djordj. pu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: John [present] says the statement-that George [past] goes-to the market.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. pu cusku le se du'u la djordj. ca klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: John [past] says the statement-that George [present] goes-to the market.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. pu cusku le se du'u la djordj. pu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: John [past] says the statement-that George [past] goes-to the market.

section.para:
Probably the most counterintuitive of the Lojban examples is . The ca looks quite odd, as if George were going to the market right now, rather than back when John spoke. But this ca is really a ca with respect to a reference point specified by the outer pu. This behavior is the same as the additive behavior of multiple tenses in the same bridi, as explained in
.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. pu cusku le se du'u la .alis pu cusku le se du'u la djordj. pu cusku le se du'u la maris. nau klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: John [past] says the statement-that Alice [past] says the statement-that George [past] says the statement that Mary [now] goes-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: John said that Alice had said that George had earlier said that Mary is now going to the market.

section.para: sticky tenseseffect of nau on naueffect on sticky tenses The use of nau does not affect sticky tenses.

section.title: Tense relations between sentences
section.para: tense with sumti tcitaasymmetry of The sumti tcita method, explained in , of asserting a tense relationship between two events suffers from asymmetry. Specifically,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba cu cadzu le bisli zu'a le nu le nanmu cu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The child walks-on the ice [left] the event-of the man bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The child walks on the ice to the left of where the man bites the dog.

section.para: sentencesconnecting with tense tenseconnecting sentences in with which specifies an imaginary journey leftward from the man biting the dog to the child walking on the ice, claims only that the child walks on the ice. By the nature of le nu, the man's biting the dog is merely referred to without being claimed. If it seems desirable to claim both, each event can be expressed as a main sentence bridi, with a special form of i connecting them:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku .izu'abo le verba cu cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man bites the dog. [Left] the child walks-on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The man bites the dog. To the left, the child walks on the ice.

section.para: .izu'abo is a compound cmavo: the i separates the sentences and the zu'a is the tense. The bo is required to prevent the zu'a from gobbling up the following sumti, namely le verba.

tensesumti tcita form contrasted with connected sentences tense connection of sentencescontrasted with sumti tcita form imaginary journeyorigin of in tense-connected sentences tense connection of sentencesorder of Note that the bridi in appear in the reverse order from their appearance in . With .izu'abo (and all other afterthought tense connectives) the sentence specifying the origin of the journey comes first. This is a natural order for sentences, but requires some care when converting between this form and the sumti tcita form.
means the same thing as:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku .i zu'a la'edi'u le verba cu cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man bites the dog. [Left] the-referent-of-the-last-sentence the child walks-on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The man bites the dog. Left of what I just mentioned, the child walks on the ice.

section.para: tense connected sentencesimportance of bo in If the bo is omitted in , the meaning changes:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku .i zu'a le verba cu cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man bites the dog. [Left] the child [something] walks-on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The man bites the dog. To the left of the child, something walks on the ice.

section.para: Here the first place of the second sentence is unspecified, because zu'a has absorbed the sumti le verba.
Do not confuse either or with the following:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku .i zu'aku le verba cu cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man bites the dog. [Left] the child walks-on the ice.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The man bites the dog. Left of me, the child walks on the ice.

section.para: In , the origin point is the speaker, as is usual with zu'aku. makes the origin point of the tense the event described by the first sentence.

tense connected sentencesforethought mode Two sentences may also be connected in forethought by a tense relationship. Just like afterthought tense connection, forethought tense connection claims both sentences, and in addition claims that the time or space relationship specified by the tense holds between the events the two sentences describe.

imaginary journeyorigin in tense forethought sentence connection sentencesforethought tense connection of forethought tense connection of sentencesorder of The origin sentence is placed first, preceded by a tense plus gi. Another gi is used to separate the sentences:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pugi mi klama le zarci gi mi klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [past] I go-to the market [,] I go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Before I go to the market, I go to the house.

section.para: A parallel construction can be used to express a tense relationship between sumti:

indexterm.secondary: origin in tense forethought sumti connection

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama pugi le zarci gi le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to [past] the market [,] the house.

section.para:
Because English does not have any direct way of expressing a tense-like relationship between nouns,
cannot be expressed in English without paraphrasing it either into or else into I go to the house before the market, which is ambiguous – is the market going?

bridi-tailsforethought tense connection of imaginary journeyorigin in tense forethought bridi-tail connection forethought tense connection of bridi-tailsorder of Finally, a third forethought construction expresses a tense relationship between bridi-tails rather than whole bridi. (The construct known as a bridi-tail is explained fully in ; roughly speaking, it is a selbri, possibly with following sumti.) is equivalent in meaning to and :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pugi klama le zarci gi klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] go-to the market [,] go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I, before going to the market, go to the house.

section.para: tense connection of bridi-tailsmeaning of tense connection of sumtimeaning of In both and , the underlying sentences mi klama le zarci and mi klama le zdani are not claimed; only the relationship in time between them is claimed.

tense afterthought connection formsselma'o allowed tense forethought connection formsselma'o allowed tense connectionexpansions of tense connectionequivalent meanings Both the forethought and the afterthought forms are appropriate with PU, ZI, FAhA, VA, and ZAhO tenses. In all cases, the equivalent forms are (where X and Y stand for sentences, and TENSE for a tense cmavo):

section.title: Tensed logical connectives
section.para:
tensed logical connectives logical connectivestensed The Lojban tense system interacts with the Lojban logical connective system. That system is a separate topic, explained in
and touched on only in summary here. By the rules of the logical connective system, through 17.3 are equivalent in meaning:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la teris. satre le mlatu .ije la teris. satre le ractu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Terry strokes the cat. And Terry strokes the rabbit.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la teris. satre le mlatu gi'e satre le ractu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Terry strokes the cat and strokes the rabbit.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la teris. satre le mlatu .e le ractu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Terry strokes the cat and the rabbit.

section.para: Suppose we wish to add a tense relationship to the logical connective and? To say that Terry strokes the cat and later strokes the rabbit, we can combine a logical connective with a tense connective by placing the logical connective first, then the tense, and then the cmavo bo, thus:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la teris. satre le mlatu .ijebabo la teris. satre le ractu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Terry strokes the cat. And then Terry strokes the rabbit.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la teris. satre le mlatu gi'ebabo satre le ractu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Terry strokes the cat, and then strokes the rabbit.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la teris. satre le mlatu .ebabo le ractu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Terry strokes the cat and then the rabbit.

section.para: tensed logically connected sumti tensed logically connected bridi-tails tensed logically connected sentences through 17.6 are equivalent in meaning. They are also analogous to through respectively. The bo is required for the same reason as in : to prevent the ba from functioning as a sumti tcita for the following sumti (or, in , from being attached to the following selbri).

tensed logical connectiveswith tu'eâ¦tu'u tensed logical connectiveswith keâ¦ke'e In addition to the bo construction of through , there is also a form of tensed logical connective with
ke…ke'e ( tu'e…tu'u for sentences). The logical connective system makes through equivalent in meaning:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli .ije tu'e mi bevri le gerku .ija mi bevri le mlatu tu'u
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack. And (I carry the dog. And/or I carry the cat).
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I carry the sack. And I carry the dog, or I carry the cat, or I carry both.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli gi'eke bevri le gerku gi'a bevri le mlatu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack and (carry the dog and/or carry the cat).
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I carry the sack, and also carry the dog or carry the cat or carry both.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli .eke le gerku .a le mlatu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack and (the dog or the cat).
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I carry the sack and also the dog or the cat or both.

section.para: Note the uniformity of the Lojban, as contrasted with the variety of ways in which the English provides for the correct grouping. In all cases, the meaning is that I carry the sack in any case, and either the cat or the dog or both.
To express that I carry the sack first (earlier in time), and then the dog or the cat or both simultaneously, I can insert tenses to form through :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli .ije ba tu'e mi bevri le gerku .ijacabo mi bevri le mlatu tu'u
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack. And [future] (I carry the dog. And/or [present] I carry the cat.)
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I carry the sack. And then I will carry the dog or I will carry the cat or I will carry both at once.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli gi'ebake bevri le gerku gi'acabo bevri le mlatu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack and [future] (carry the dog and/or [present] carry the cat).
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I carry the sack and then will carry the dog or carry the cat or carry both at once.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli .ebake le gerku .acabo le mlatu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack and [future] (the cat and/or [present] the dog).
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I carry the sack, and then the cat or the dog or both at once.

section.para: tensed logically connected sumtiwith grouping tensed logically connected bridi-tailswith grouping tensed logically connected sentenceswith grouping through are equivalent in meaning to each other, and correspond to the tenseless through respectively.

section.title: Tense negation
section.para: ZAhO selma'ocontradictory negation of FAhA selma'ocontradictory negation of PU selma'ocontradictory negation of negationof tenses tensesnegating Any bridi which involves tenses of selma'o PU, FAhA, or ZAhO can be contradicted by a -nai suffixed to the tense cmavo. Some examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi punai klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [not] go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I didn't go to the market.

section.para: negation of tensesmeaning of tensescontradictory negation of with nai As a contradictory negation, implies that the bridi as a whole is false without saying anything about what is true. When the negated tense is a sumti tcita, -nai negation indicates that the stated relationship does not hold:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci canai le nu do klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [present] [not] the event-of you go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: It is not true that I went to the market at the same time that you went to the house.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu batci le gerku ne'inai le kumfa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man bites the dog [within] [not] the room.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The man didn't bite the dog inside the room.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi morsi ca'onai le nu mi jmive
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-dead [continuitive - negated] the event-of I live.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: It is false that I am dead during my life.

section.para: NAhE selma'o tensecontradictory negation contrasted with scalar negation of tensescalar negation contrasted with contradictory negation of tensescalar negation of with NAhE It is also possible to perform scalar negation of whole tense constructs by placing a member of NAhE before them. Unlike contradictory negation, scalar negation asserts a truth: that the bridi is true with some tense other than that specified. The following examples are scalar negation analogues of to :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e pu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [non-] [past] go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go to the market other than in the past.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu batci le gerku to'e ne'i le kumfa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man bites the dog [opposite-of] [within] the room.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The man bites the dog outside the room.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci na'e ca le nu do klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [non-] [present] the event-of you go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I went to the market at a time other than the time at which you went to the house.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi morsi na'e ca'o le nu mi jmive
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-dead [non-] [continuitive] the event-of I live.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I am dead other than during my life.

section.para: FAhA selma'o PU selma'o scalar negation of tensesselma'o allowed with contradictory negation of tensesselma'o allowed with Unlike -nai contradictory negation, scalar negation of tenses is not limited to PU and FAhA:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba na'e ri'u cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The child [non-] [right] walks-on the ice
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The child walks on the ice other than to my right.

section.para: ROI selma'oscalar negation of TAhE selma'oscalar negation of The use of -nai on cmavo of TAhE and ROI has already been discussed in ; this use is also a scalar negation.

section.title: Actuality, potentiality, capability: CAhA
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

innate capabilitiesexpressing implicitly potential eventsexpressing implicitly Lojban bridi without tense markers may not necessarily refer to actual events: they may also refer to capabilities or potential events. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ro datka cu flulimna
interlinear-gloss.gloss: All ducks are-float-swimmers.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: All ducks swim by floating.

section.para: actualityLojban contrasted with English in implying tenseLojban contrasted with English in implying actuality is a Lojban truth, even though the colloquial English translation is false or at best ambiguous. This is because the tenseless Lojban bridi doesn't necessarily claim that every duck is swimming or floating now or even at a specific time or place. Even if we add a tense marker to ,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ro datka ca flulimna
interlinear-gloss.gloss: All ducks [present] are-float-swimmers.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: All ducks are now swimming by floating.

section.para: the resulting might still be considered a truth, even though the colloquial English seems even more likely to be false. All ducks have the potential of swimming even if they are not exercising that potential at present. To get the full flavor of All ducks are now swimming, we must append a marker from selma'o CAhA to the tense, and say:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ro datka ca ca'a flulimna
interlinear-gloss.gloss: All ducks [present] [actual] are-float-swimmers.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: All ducks are now actually swimming by floating.

section.para: sticky tensesand CAhA CAhA selma'omaking sticky CAhA selma'oorder in tense construct actual eventsexplicitly expressing A CAhA cmavo is always placed after any other tense cmavo, whether for time or for space. However, a CAhA cmavo comes before ki, so that a CAhA condition can be made sticky.
is false in both Lojban and English, since it claims that the swimming is an actual, present fact, true of every duck that exists, whereas in fact there is at least one duck that is not swimming now.

innate capabilityexpressing explicitly Furthermore, some ducks are dead (and therefore sink); some ducks have just hatched (and do not know how to swim yet), and some ducks have been eaten by predators (and have ceased to exist as separate objects at all). Nevertheless, all these ducks have the innate capability of swimming – it is part of the nature of duckhood. The cmavo
ka'e expresses this notion of innate capability:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ro datka ka'e flulimna
interlinear-gloss.gloss: All ducks [capable] are-float-swimmers.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: All ducks are innately capable of swimming.

section.para: innate propertiesextension of from mass to individuals Under some epistemologies, innate capability can be extended in order to apply the innate properties of a mass to which certain individuals belong to the individuals themselves, even if those individuals are themselves not capable of fulfilling the claim of the bridi. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. ka'e viska
interlinear-gloss.gloss: John [capable] sees.
John is innately capable of seeing.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: John can see.

section.para: innate propertiesextension to individuals not actually capable might be true about a human being named John, even though he has been blind since birth, because the ability to see is innately built into his nature as a human being. It is theoretically possible that conditions might occur that would enable John to see (a great medical discovery, for example). On the other hand,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le cukta ka'e viska
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The book [capable] sees.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The book can see.

section.para: is not true in most epistemologies, since the ability to see is not part of the innate nature of a book.

undemonstrated potentialexpressing Consider once again the newly hatched ducks mentioned earlier. They have the potential of swimming, but have not yet demonstrated that potential. This may be expressed using nu'o, the cmavo of CAhA for undemonstrated potential:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ro cifydatka nu'o flulimna
interlinear-gloss.gloss: All infant-ducks [can but has not] are-float-swimmers.
All infant ducks have an undemonstrated potential for swimming by floating.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Baby ducks can swim but haven't yet.

section.para: demonstrated potentialexpressing Contrariwise, if Frank is not blind from birth, then pu'i is appropriate:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la frank. pu'i viska
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Frank [can and has] sees.
Frank has demonstrated a potential for seeing.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Frank can see and has seen.

section.para:
actualityexpressing in past/future potentialexpressing in past/future Note that the glosses given at the beginning of this section for ca'a,
nu'o, and
pu'i incorporate
ca into their meaning, and are really correct for ca ca'a,
ca nu'o, and
ca pu'i. However, the CAhA cmavo are perfectly meaningful with other tenses than the present:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu ca'a klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [actual] go-to the store.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I actually went to the store.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la frank. ba nu'o klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Frank [future] [can but has not] goes-to the store.
Frank could have, but will not have, gone to the store
interlinear-gloss.natlang: (at some understood moment in the future).

section.para: tenses with elided CAhAmeaning As always in Lojban tenses, a missing CAhA can have an indeterminate meaning, or the context can be enough to disambiguate it. Saying

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta jelca
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That burns/is-burning/might-burn/will-burn.

section.para: with no CAhA specified can translate the two very different English sentences That is on fire and That is inflammable. The first demands immediate action (usually), whereas the second merely demands caution. The two cases can be disambiguated with:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ca ca'a jelca
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That [present] [actual] burns.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is on fire.

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ka'e jelca
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That [capable] burns.
That is capable of burning.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is inflammable.

section.para: observative with elided CAhAconvention When no indication is given, as in the simple observative

interlinear-gloss.jbo: jelca
interlinear-gloss.natlang: It burns!

section.para: the prudent Lojbanist will assume the meaning Fire!

section.title: Logical and non-logical connections between tenses
section.para: Like many things in Lojban, tenses may be logically connected; logical connection is explained in more detail in . Some of the terminology in this section will be clear only if you already understand logical connectives.

JA selma'o logically connected tensesexpansion to sentences tenseslogically connected with JA logically connected tenseswith JA The appropriate logical connectives belong to selma'o JA. A logical connective between tenses can always be expanded to one between sentences:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu je ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] and [future] go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I went and will go to the market.

section.para: means the same as:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu klama le zarci .ije mi ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] go-to the market. And I [future] go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I went to the market, and I will go to the market.

section.para: tensesconnectedwith negation Tense connection and tense negation are combined in:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi punai je canai je ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [not] and [present] [not] and [future] go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I haven't yet gone to the market, but I will in future.

section.para: is far more specific than

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [future] go-to the market.

section.para: which only says that I will go, without claiming anything about my past or present. ba does not imply punai or canai; to compel that interpretation, either a logical connection or a ZAhO is needed.

connected tensesnegation of compared with negation in connective Tense negation can often be removed in favor of negation in the logical connective itself. The following examples are equivalent in meaning:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi mo'izu'anai je mo'iri'u cadzu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [motion] [left-not] and [motion] [right] walk.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I walk not leftward but rightward.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi mo'izu'a naje mo'iri'u cadzu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [motion] [left] not-and [motion] [right] walk.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I walk not leftward but rightward.

section.para: tensespossible groupings of tensesforethought logical connections There are no forethought logical connections between tenses allowed by the grammar, to keep tenses simpler. Nor is there any way to override simple left-grouping of the connectives, the Lojban default.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi puza bi'o bazu vasxu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] [medium] from ... to [future] [long] breathe.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I breathe from a medium time ago till a long time to come.

section.para: (It is to be hoped that I have a long life ahead of me.)
One additional use of non-logical connectives within tenses is discussed in . Other uses will probably be identified in future.

section.title: Sub-events
section.para: tensesnon-logical connection of for sub-events Another application of non-logical tense connection is to talk about sub-events of events. Consider a six-shooter: a gun which can fire six bullets in succession before reloading. If I fire off the entire magazine twice, I can express the fact in Lojban thus:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi reroi pi'u xaroi cecla le seldanti
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [twice] [cross-product] [six times] shoot the projectile-launcher.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: On two occasions, I fire the gun six times.

section.para:
cross productwith tenses Cartesian productwith tenses pi'uuse in connecting tenses It would be confusing, though grammatical, to run the reroi and the xaroi directly together. However, the non-logical connective pi'u expresses a Cartesian product (also known as a cross product) of two sets. In this case, there is a set of two firings each of which is represented by a set of six shots, for twelve shots in all (hence the name
product: the product of 2 and 6 is 12). Its use specifies very precisely what occurs.

event contoursstrings of interval propertiesstrings of In fact, you can specify strings of interval properties and event contours within a single tense without the use of a logical or non-logical connective cmavo. This allows tenses of the type:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djordj. ca'o co'a ciska
interlinear-gloss.gloss: George [continuitive] [initiative] writes.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: George continues to start to write.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi reroi ca'o xaroi darxi le damri
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [twice] [continuitive] [six times] hit the drum.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: On two occasions, I continue to beat the drum six times.

section.title: Conversion of sumti tcita: JAI
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

SE selma'o conversiondefinition Conversion is the regular Lojban process of moving around the places of a place structure. The cmavo of selma'o SE serve this purpose, exchanging the first place with one of the others:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi cu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le zarci cu se klama mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The market is-gone-to by-me.

section.para: jai with tenseas equivalent of SE in grammar tense conversionaccessing tense of bridi with jai conversionaccessing tense of bridi with jai It is also possible to bring a place that is specified by a sumti tcita (for the purposes of this chapter, a tense sumti tcita) to the front, by using jai plus the tense as the grammatical equivalent of SE:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu cu citka le cirla vi le panka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The rat eats the cheese [short distance] the park.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The rat eats the cheese in the park.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le panka cu jai vi citka le cirla fai le ratcu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The park is-the-place-of eating the cheese by-the rat.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The park is where the rat eats the cheese.

section.para: tense conversionaccessing original first place with fai In , the construction JAI+tense converts the location sumti into the first place. The previous first place has nowhere to go, since the location sumti is not a numbered place; however, it can be inserted back into the bridi with fai, the indefinite member of selma'o FA.
(The other members of FA are used to mark the first, second, etc. places of a bridi explicitly:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: fa mi cu klama fe le zarci

section.para: means the same as

interlinear-gloss.jbo: fe le zarci cu klama fa mi

section.para: as well as the simple

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi cu klama le zarci

section.para: in which the place structure is determined by position.)
LE selma'o tense conversionuse in sumti descriptions Like SE conversion, JAI+tense conversion is especially useful in descriptions with LE selma'o:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi viska le jai vi citka be le cirla
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I saw the place-of eating the cheese.

section.para: Here the eater of the cheese is elided, so no fai appears.
tense conversionof temporal tenses Of course, temporal tenses are also usable with JAI:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi djuno fi le jai ca morsi be fai la djan.
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I know about the [present] is-dead of-the-one-called John.
I know the time of John's death.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I know when John died.

section.title: Tenses versus modals
section.para: modalscontrasted with tenses in semantics tensescontrasted with modals in semantics modalscompared with tenses in syntax tensescompared with modals in syntax Grammatically, every use of tenses seen so far is exactly paralleled by some use of modals as explained in . Modals and tenses alike can be followed by sumti, can appear before the selbri, can be used in pure and mixed connections, can participate in JAI conversions. The parallelism is perfect. However, there is a deep difference in the semantics of tense constructs and modal constructs, grounded in historical differences between the two forms. Originally, modals and tenses were utterly different things in earlier versions of Loglan; only in Lojban have they become grammatically interchangeable. And even now, differences in semantics continue to be maintained.
modalsimportance of 1st sumti place for sumti tcita use The core distinction is that whereas the modal bridi

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi nelci do mu'i le nu do nelci mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I like you with-motivation the event-of you like me.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I like you because you like me.

section.para: places the le nu sumti in the x1 place of the gismu mukti (which underlies the modal mu'i), namely the motivating event, the tensed bridi

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi nelci do ba le nu do nelci mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I like you after the event-of you like me.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I like you after you like me.

section.para: tensesimportance of 2nd sumti place for sumti tcita use places the le nu sumti in the x2 place of the gismu balvi (which underlies the tense ba), namely the point of reference for the future tense. Paraphrases of and , employing the brivla mukti and balvi explicitly, would be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nu do nelci mi cu mukti le nu mi nelci do
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The event-of you like me motivates the event-of I like you.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Your liking me is the motive for my liking you.

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nu mi nelci do cu balvi le nu do nelci mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The event-of I like you is after the event of you like me.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: My liking you follows (in time) your liking me.

section.para: afterthought sentence connectionmodal contrasted with tense As a result, the afterthought sentence-connective forms of and are, respectively:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi nelci do .imu'ibo do nelci mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I like you. [That is] Because you like me.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do nelci mi .ibabo mi nelci do
interlinear-gloss.natlang: You like me. Afterward, I like you.

section.para: In , the order of the two bridi mi nelci do and do nelci mi is the same as in . In , however, the order is reversed: the origin point do nelci mi physically appears before the future-time event mi nelci do. In both cases, the bridi characterizing the event in the x2 place appears before the bridi characterizing the event in the x1 place of mukti or balvi.

afterthought tense connectioncontrasted with forethought in likeness to modal connection forethought tense connectioncontrasted with afterthought in likeness to modal connection forethought connectionsmodal compared with tense in semantics In forethought connections, however, the asymmetry between modals and tenses is not found. The forethought equivalents of
and are

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mu'igi do nelci mi gi mi nelci do
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Because you like me, I like you.

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.jbo: bagi do nelci mi gi mi nelci do
interlinear-gloss.natlang: After you like me, I like you.

section.para: respectively.
modal sentence connectiontable of equivalent schemata The following modal sentence schemata (where X and Y represent sentences) all have the same meaning:
tense sentence connectiontable of equivalent schemata whereas the following tensed sentence schemata also have the same meaning:

neglecting the question of what is claimed. In the modal sentence schemata, the modal tag is always followed by Y, the sentence representing the event in the x1 place of the gismu that underlies the BAI. In the tensed sentences, no such simple rule exists.

section.title: Tense questions: cu'e
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

mafor tense questions tense questions with ma tense questionsmethods of asking There are two main ways to ask questions about tense. The main English tense question words are When? and Where?. These may be paraphrased respectively as At what time? and At what place? In these forms, their Lojban equivalents simply involve a tense plus ma, the Lojban sumti question:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do klama le zdani ca ma
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You go-to the house [present] [what sumti?].
You go to the house at what time?
interlinear-gloss.natlang: When do you go to the house?

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba vi ma pu cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The child [short space] [what sumti?] [past] walks-on the ice.
The child at/near what place walked on the ice?
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Where did the child walk on the ice?

section.para: modal-or-tense questionwith cu'e tense-or-modal questionswith cu'e There is also a non-specific tense and modal question, cu'e, belonging to selma'o CUhE. This can be used wherever a tense or modal construct can be used.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu'e batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man [what tense?] bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: When/Where/How does the man bite the dog?

section.para: answersto tense-or-modal questions Possible answers to might be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: va
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [medium space].
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Some ways from here.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: puzu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [past] [long time].
interlinear-gloss.natlang: A long time ago.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: vi le lunra
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [short space] The moon.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: On the moon.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pu'o
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [inchoative]
interlinear-gloss.natlang: He hasn't yet done so.

section.para: or even the modal reply (from selma'o BAI; see ):

interlinear-gloss.jbo: seka'a le briju
interlinear-gloss.gloss: With-destination the office.

section.para: modal-or-tense questionspre-specifying some information tense-or-modal questionspre-specifying some information cu'ecombining with other tense cmavo The only way to combine cu'e with other tense cmavo is through logical connection, which makes a question that pre-specifies some information:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do puzi je cu'e sombo le gurni
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You [past] [short] and [when?] sow the grain?
interlinear-gloss.natlang: You sowed the grain a little while ago; when else do you sow it?

section.para: Additionally, the logical connective itself can be replaced by a question word:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .artr. pu je'i ba nolraitru
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Arthur [past] [which?] [future] is-a-king
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Was Arthur a king or will he be?

section.para: Answers to would be logical connectives such as je, meaning both, naje meaning the latter, or jenai meaning the former.

section.title: Explicit magnitudes
section.para: It is a limitation of the VA and ZI system of specifying magnitudes that they can only prescribe vague magnitudes: small, medium, or large. In order to express both an origin point and an exact distance, the Lojban construction called a termset is employed. (Termsets are explained further in and .) It is grammatical for a termset to be placed after a tense or modal tag rather than a sumti, which allows both the origin of the imaginary journey and its distance to be specified. Here is an example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la frank. sanli zu'a nu'i la djordj. la'u lo mitre be li mu [nu'u]
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Frank stands [left] [start termset] George [quantity] a thing-measuring-in-meters the-number 5 [end termset].
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Frank is standing five meters to the left of George.

section.para: Here the termset extends from the nu'i to the implicit nu'u at the end of the sentence, and includes the terms la djordj., which is the unmarked origin point, and the tagged sumti lo mitre be li mu, which the cmavo la'u (of selma'o BAI, and meaning with quantity; see ) marks as a quantity. Both terms are governed by the tag zu'a

It is not necessary to have both an origin point and an explicit magnitude: a termset may have only a single term in it. A less precise version of
is:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la frank. sanli zu'a nu'i la'u lo mitre be li mu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Frank stands [left] [termset] [quantity] a thing-measuring-in-meters the-number 5.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Frank stands five meters to the left.

section.title: Finally (an exercise for the much-tried reader)

interlinear-gloss.jbo: .a'o do pu seju ba roroi ca'o fe'e su'oroi jimpe fi le lojbo temci selsku ciste
