repeating decimalsmarking start of repeating portion repeating decimalsexpressing with numerical punctuation Note that the ra'e marks unambiguously where the repeating portion
142857 begins.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ci mu ce'i
interlinear-gloss.gloss: three five percent

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pa ki'o re ci vo ki'o mu xa ze
interlinear-gloss.gloss: one comma two three four comma five six seven

section.para: commas in numberswith elided digits It is also possible to have less than three digits between successive ki'o s, in which case zeros are assumed to have been elided:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pa ki'o re ci ki'o vo
interlinear-gloss.gloss: one comma two three comma four

section.para:
In the same way, ki'o can be used after
pi to divide fractions into groups of three:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pi ki'o re re
interlinear-gloss.gloss: point comma two two

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pi pa ki'o pa re ki'o pa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: point one comma one two comma one

section.title: Special numbers
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

fractionmeaning with elided numerator and denominator numbersspecial The last cmavo is the same as the fraction sign cmavo: a fraction sign with neither numerator nor denominator represents the golden ratio.
Numbers can have any of these digit, punctuation, and special-number cmavo of Sections 2, 3, and 4 in any combination:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ma'u ci'i
ci ka'o re
interlinear-gloss.natlang: 3i2 (a complex number equivalent to 3 + 2i)

section.para:
ka'oas special number compared with as numerical punctuation complex numbersexpressing Note that ka'o is both a special number (meaning
i) and a number punctuation mark (separating the real and the imaginary parts of a complex number).

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ci'i no
interlinear-gloss.natlang: infinity zero
ℵ0 (a transfinite cardinal)

section.para: The special numbers pai and te'o are mathematically important, which is why they are given their own cmavo:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pai
interlinear-gloss.natlang: pi, Ï

interlinear-gloss.jbo: te'o

section.para: numerical punctuationundefined However, many combinations are as yet undefined:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pa pi re pi ci
pa ni'u re
interlinear-gloss.gloss: 1 negative-sign 2

section.para: subtraction operatorcontrasted with negative sign negative signcontrasted with subtraction operator is not 1 minus 2, which is represented by a different cmavo sequence altogether. It is a single number which has not been assigned a meaning. There are many such numbers which have no well-defined meaning; they may be used for experimental purposes or for future expansion of the Lojban number system.

It is possible, of course, that some of these oddities do have a meaningful use in some restricted area of mathematics. A mathematician appropriating these structures for specialized use needs to consider whether some other branch of mathematics would use the structure differently.
More information on numbers may be found in to .

section.title: Simple infix expressions and equations
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:
mathematical notationinfix Let us begin at the beginning: one plus one equals two. In Lojban, that sentence translates to:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li pa su'i pa du li re
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number one plus one equals the-number two.

section.para: dugrammar of mathematical equalityexpressing , a mekso sentence, is a regular Lojban bridi that exploits mekso features. du is the predicate meaning x1 is mathematically equal to x2. It is a cmavo for conciseness, but it has the same grammatical uses as any brivla. Outside mathematical contexts, du means x1 is identical with x2 or x1 is the same object as x2.

numbersusing for quantification contrasted with talking about numberstalking about contrasted with using for quantification number articleexplanation of use thefor talking about numbers themselves articlenumber The cmavo li is the number article. It is required whenever a sentence talks about numbers as numbers, as opposed to using numbers to quantify things. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ci prenu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: the three persons

section.para:
requires no li article, because the
ci is being used to specify the number of prenu. However, the sentence

interlinear-gloss.jbo: levi sfani cu grake li ci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: This fly masses-in-grams the-number three.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: This fly has a mass of 3 grams.

section.para:
units of measurementexpressing measurementsexpressing requires li because ci is being used as a sumti. Note that this is the way in which measurements are stated in Lojban: all the predicates for units of length, mass, temperature, and so on have the measured object as the first place and a number as the second place. Using
li for le in would produce

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ci prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number 3 is-a-person.

section.para: which is grammatical but nonsensical: numbers are not persons.

addition operatorcontrasted with positive sign positive signcontrasted with addition operator additiona mathematical operator mathematical operators The cmavo su'i belongs to selma'o VUhU, which is composed of mathematical operators, and means
addition. As mentioned before, it is distinct from ma'u which means the positive sign as an indication of a positive number:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ma'u pa su'i ni'u pa du li no
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number positive-sign one plus negative-sign one equals the-number zero.

section.para: Of course, it is legal to have complex mekso on both sides of du:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li mu su'i pa du li ci su'i ci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number five plus one equals the-number three plus three.

section.para:
conversion into sumti from mekso conversion of mekso into sumti lias converter of mekso into sumti general sumticontrasted with operands operandscontrasted with general sumti VUhU operands operators of VUhUgrammar of operands duwith complex mekso on both sides Why don't we say li mu su'i li pa rather than just li mu su'i pa? The answer is that VUhU operators connect mekso operands (numbers, in ), not general sumti.
li is used to make the entire mekso into a sumti, which then plays the roles applicable to other sumti: in , filling the places of a bridi

precedencemathematical default operator left-right groupingas Lojban default operator precedencein Lojban default calculator mathematicsas default in Lojban By default, Lojban mathematics is like simple calculator mathematics: there is no notion of
operator precedence. Consider the following example, where
pi'i means times, the multiplication operator:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ci su'i vo pi'i mu du li reci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number three plus four times five equals the-number two-three.

section.para:
Is the Lojban version of true? No! 3 + 4 Ã 5 is indeed 23, because the usual conventions of mathematics state that multiplication takes precedence over addition; that is, the multiplication
4 Ã 5 is done first, giving 20, and only then the addition 3 + 20. But VUhU operators by default are done left to right, like other Lojban grouping, and so a truthful bridi would be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ci su'i vo pi'i mu du li cimu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number three plus four times five equals the-number three-five.

section.para: default operator precedencecontrasted with mekso goal Here we calculate 3 + 4 first, giving 7, and then calculate 7 Ã 5 second, leading to the result 35. While possessing the advantage of simplicity, this result violates the design goal of matching the standards of mathematics. What can be done?

operator precedenceeffect of pragmatic convention operator precedenceand mathematical notation mathematical notationand operator precedence There are three solutions, all of which will probably be used to some degree. The first solution is to ignore the problem. People will say li ci su'i vo pi'i mu and mean 23 by it, because the notion that multiplication takes precedence over addition is too deeply ingrained to be eradicated by Lojban parsing, which totally ignores semantics. This convention essentially allows semantics to dominate syntax in this one area.

operator precedence in other languages operator precedencerationale for default left-grouping (Why not hard-wire the precedences into the grammar, as is done in computer programming languages? Essentially because there are too many operators, known and unknown, with levels of precedence that vary according to usage. The programming language 'C' has 13 levels of precedence, and its list of operators is not even extensible. For Lojban this approach is just not practical. In addition, hard-wired precedence could not be overridden in mathematical systems such as spreadsheets where the conventions are different.)

operator precedencegeneralized explicit specification The second solution is to use explicit means to specify the precedence of operators. This approach is fully general, but clumsy, and will be explained in .

bi'eeffect on following operator operator precedencescope modification with bi'e The third solution is simple but not very general. When an operator is prefixed with the cmavo bi'e (of selma'o BIhE), it becomes automatically of higher precedence than other operators not so prefixed. Thus,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ci su'i vo bi'e pi'i mu du li reci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number three plus four-times-five equals the-number two-three.

section.para:
is a truthful Lojban bridi. If more than one operator has a bi'e prefix, grouping is from the right; multiple
bi'e prefixes on a single operator are not allowed.

parenthesismathematical operator precedencespecifying by parenthesis In addition, of course, Lojban has the mathematical parentheses vei and ve'o, which can be used just like their written equivalents ( and ) to group expressions in any way desired:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li vei ny. su'i pa ve'o pi'i vei ny. su'i pa [ve'o] du li ny. [bi'e] te'a re su'i re bi'e pi'i ny. su'i pa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number (n plus one) times (n plus one) equals the-number n-power-two plus two-times- n plus 1.

section.para:
lerfu stringsinterpretation of contrasted with normal mathematical interpretation lerfu stringsin mathematical expressions There are several new usages in : te'a means
raised to the power, and we also see the use of the lerfu word ny, representing the letter n. In mekso, letters stand for just what they do in ordinary mathematics: variables. The parser will accept a string of lerfu words (called a lerfu string) as the equivalent of a single lerfu word, in agreement with computer-science conventions; abc is a single variable, not the equivalent of a Ã b Ã c. (Of course, a local convention could state that the value of a variable like abc, with a multi-lerfu name, was equal to the values of the variables a, b, and c multiplied together.)

The explicit operator pi'i is required in the Lojban verbal form whereas multiplication is implicit in the symbolic form. Note that
ve'o (the right parenthesis) is an elidable terminator: the first use of it in is required, but the second use (marked by square brackets) could be elided. Additionally, the first
bi'e (also marked by square brackets) is not necessary to get the proper grouping, but it is included here for symmetry with the other one.

section.title: Forethought operators (Polish notation, functions)
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

The infix form explained so far is reasonable for many purposes, but it is limited and rigid. It works smoothly only where all operators have exactly two operands, and where precedences can either be assumed from context or are limited to just two levels, with some help from parentheses.

But there are many operators which do not have two operands, or which have a variable number of operands. The preferred form of expression in such cases is the use of forethought operators, also known as Polish notation. In this style of writing mathematics, the operator comes first and the operands afterwards:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li su'i paboi reboi ci[boi] du li xa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number the-sum-of one two three equals the-number six.

section.para: Note that the normally elidable number terminator boi is required after pa and re because otherwise the reading would be pareci= 123. It is not required after ci but is inserted here in brackets for the sake of symmetry. The only time boi is required is, as in , when there are two consecutive numbers or lerfu strings.

Forethought mekso can use any number of operands, in , three. How do we know how many operands there are in ambiguous circumstances? The usual Lojban solution is employed: an elidable terminator, namely ku'e. Here is an example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li py. su'i va'a ny. ku'e su'i zy du li xy.
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number p plus negative-of( n) plus z equals the-number x.

section.para: where we know that va'a is a forethought operator because there is no operand preceding it.

va'a is the numerical negation operator, of selma'o VUhU. In contrast,
vu'u is not used for numerical negation, but only for subtraction, as it always has two or more operands. Do not confuse va'a and vu'u, which are operators, with ni'u, which is part of a number.

In , the operator va'a and the terminator ku'e serve in effect as parentheses. (The regular parentheses vei and ve'o are NOT used for this purpose.) If the ku'e were omitted, the su'i zy would be swallowed up by the va'a forethought operator, which would then appear to have two operands, ny and su'i zy., where the latter is also a forethought expression.

Forethought mekso is also useful for matching standard functional notation. How do we represent
z = f(x)? The answer is:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li zy du li ma'o fy.boi xy.
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number z equals the-number the-operator f x.

section.para: Again, no parentheses are used. The construct ma'o fy.boi is the equivalent of an operator, and appears in forethought here (although it could also be used as a regular infix operator). In mathematics, letters sometimes mean functions and sometimes mean variables, with only the context to tell which. Lojban chooses to accept the variable interpretation as the default, and uses the special flag ma'o to mark a lerfu string as an operator. The cmavo xy. and zy. are variables, but fy. is an operator (a function) because ma'o marks it as such. The boi is required because otherwise the xy. would look like part of the operator name. (The use of ma'o can be generalized from lerfu strings to any mekso operand: see .)

When using forethought mekso, the optional marker pe'o may be placed in front of the operator. This usage can help avoid confusion by providing clearly marked
pe'o and
ku'e pairs to delimit the operand list. to , respectively, with explicit pe'o and
ku'e:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li pe'o su'i paboi reboi ciboi ku'e du li xa
li py. su'i pe'o va'a ny. ku'e su'i zy du li xy.
li zy du li pe'o ma'o fy.boi xy. ku'e

section.para:
Note: When using forethought mekso, be sure that the operands really are operands: they cannot contain regular infix expressions unless parenthesized with
vei and ve'o. An earlier version of the complex came to grief because I forgot this rule.

section.title: Other useful selbri for mekso bridi
section.para: So far our examples have been isolated mekso (it is legal to have a bare mekso as a sentence in Lojban) and equation bridi involving du. What about inequalities such as x < 5? The answer is to use a bridi with an appropriate selbri, thus:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li xy. mleca li mu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number x is-less-than the-number 5.

section.para: Here is a partial list of selbri useful in mathematical bridi:

definition.content: x1 is identical to x2, x3, x4, ...
x1 is equal/congruent to x2 in/on property/quality/dimension/quantity x3
x1 is less than x2
x1 is greater than x2
x1 is less than or equal to x2 [du ja mleca, equal or less]
x1 is greater than or equal to x2 [du ja zmadu, equal or greater]
x1 is similar to x2 [tarmi dunli, shape-equal]
x1 is isomorphic to x2 [stura dunli, structure-equal]
x1 is a member of set x2
x1 is a subset of set x2 [girzu pagbu, set-part]
x1 is approximately equal to x2 [namcu jibni, number-near]
x1 is a component with function x2 of system x3

section.para:
Note the difference between dunli and
du; dunli has a third place that specifies the kind of equality that is meant.
du refers to actual identity, and can have any number of places:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: py. du xy.boi zy.
interlinear-gloss.gloss: p is-identical-to x z

section.para: Lojban bridi can have only one predicate, so the du is not repeated.
Any of these selbri may usefully be prefixed with na, the contradictory negation cmavo, to indicate that the relation is false:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li re su'i re na du li mu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-number 2 + 2 is-not equal-to the-number 5.

section.para: As usual in Lojban, negated bridi say what is false, and do not say anything about what might be true.

section.title: Indefinite numbers
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

Not all the cmavo of PA represent numbers in the usual mathematical sense. For example, the cmavo ro means all or each. This number does not have a definite value in the abstract: li ro is undefined. But when used to count or quantify something, the parallel between ro and pa is clearer:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu pa prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at one person

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu ro prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at all persons

section.para: might be true, whereas is almost certainly false.

The cmavo so'a,
so'e,
so'i,
so'o, and
so'u represent a set of indefinite numbers less than
ro. As you go down an alphabetical list, the magnitude decreases:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu so'a prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at almost-all persons

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu so'e prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at most persons

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu so'i prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at many persons

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu so'o prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at several persons

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu so'u prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at a-few persons

section.para:
The English equivalents are only rough: the cmavo provide space for up to five indefinite numbers between
ro and no, with a built-in ordering. In particular, so'e does not mean
most in the sense of a majority or more than half.

Each of these numbers, plus ro, may be prefixed with pi (the decimal point) in order to make a fractional form which represents part of a whole rather than some elements of a totality.
piro therefore means the whole of:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi citka piro lei nanba
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I eat the-whole-of the-mass-of bread

section.para: Similarly, piso'a means almost the whole of; and so on down to piso'u, a tiny part of. These numbers are particularly appropriate with masses, which are usually measured rather than counted, as shows.

In addition to these cmavo, there is no'o, meaning
the typical value, and
pino'o, meaning the typical portion: Sometimes no'o can be translated
the average value, but the average in question is not, in general, a mathematical mean, median, or mode; these would be more appropriately represented by operators.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu no'o prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at a-typical-number-of persons

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi citka pino'o lei nanba
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I eat a-typical-amount-of the-mass-of bread.

section.para: timesimplicit expression of timesexplicit expression of da'a is a related cmavo meaning all but:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu da'a re prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at all-but two persons

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu da'a so'u prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at all-but a-few persons

section.para: is similar in meaning to .
da'adefault number for If no number follows da'a, then pa is assumed; da'a by itself means all but one, or in ordinal contexts all but the last:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ro ratcu ka'e citka da'a ratcu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: All rats can eat all-but-one rats.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: All rats can eat all other rats.

section.para:
(The use of da'a means that does not require that all rats can eat themselves, but does allow it. Each rat has one rat it cannot eat, but that one might be some rat other than itself. Context often dictates that
itself is, indeed, the other rat.)
ni'uwith elided number ma'uwith elided number As mentioned in , ma'u and ni'u are also legal numbers, and they mean some positive number and some negative number respectively.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ci vu'u re du li ma'u
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-number 3 â 2 = some-positive-number

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ci vu'u vo du li ni'u
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-number 3 â 4 = some-negative-number

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ponse ma'u rupnu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I possess a-positive-number-of currency-units.

section.para:
indefinite valuessubjective subjective amountsexpressing All of the numbers discussed so far are objective, even if indefinite. If there are exactly six superpowers ( rairgugde, superlative-states) in the world, then ro rairgugde means the same as xa rairgugde. It is often useful, however, to express subjective indefinite values. The cmavo
rau (enough),
du'e (too many), and
mo'a (too few) are then appropriate:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ponse rau rupnu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I possess enough currency-units.

section.para:
indefinite portionssubjective subjective portionsexpressing Like the so'a-series,
rau,
du'e, and
mo'a can be preceded by
pi; for example, pirau means a sufficient part of.

definite numberscombined with indefinite indefinite numberscombined with definite Another possibility is that of combining definite and indefinite numbers into a single number. This usage implies that the two kinds of numbers have the same value in the given context:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi viska le rore gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I saw the all-of/two dogs.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I saw both dogs.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi speni so'ici prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-married-to many/three persons.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I am married to three persons (which is many in the circumstances).

section.para: assumes a mostly monogamous culture by stating that three is many.

section.title: Approximation and inexact numbers
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

ji'ieffect of placement approximate numbersexpressing The cmavo ji'i (of selma'o PA) is used in several ways to indicate approximate or rounded numbers. If it appears at the beginning of a number, the whole number is approximate:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ji'i vo no
interlinear-gloss.gloss: approximation four zero
interlinear-gloss.natlang: approximately 40

section.para: approximate numbersexpressing some exactness of If ji'i appears in the middle of a number, all the digits following it are approximate:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: vo no ji'i mu no
interlinear-gloss.gloss: four zero approximation five zero
interlinear-gloss.natlang: roughly 4050 (where the four thousand is exact, but the fifty is approximate)

section.para: rounded numbersexpressing truncation of numberexpressing If ji'i appears at the end of a number, it indicates that the number has been rounded. In addition, it can then be followed by a sign cmavo ( ma'u or ni'u), which indicate truncation towards positive or negative infinity respectively.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: re pi ze re ji'i
interlinear-gloss.gloss: two point seven two approximation
interlinear-gloss.natlang: 2.72 (rounded)

interlinear-gloss.jbo: re pi ze re ji'i ma'u
interlinear-gloss.gloss: two point seven two approximation positive-sign
interlinear-gloss.natlang: 2.72 (rounded up)

interlinear-gloss.jbo: re pi ze pa ji'i ni'u
interlinear-gloss.gloss: two point seven one approximation negative-sign
interlinear-gloss.natlang: 2.71 (rounded down)

section.para: ji'iwith elided number through are all approximations to te'o (exponential e). ji'i can also appear by itself, in which case it means approximately the typical value in this context.

inexact numbers with bounds The four cmavo su'e,
su'o, me'i, and
za'u, also of selma'o PA, express inexact numbers with upper or lower bounds:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu su'e re prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at at-most two persons

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu su'o re prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at at-least two persons

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu me'i re prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at less-than two persons

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu za'u re prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at more-than two persons

section.para:
pluralLojban equivalent of exact numberexpressing at mostcontrasted with more thanat least, less than at leastcontrasted with more thanless than, at most more thancontrasted with less thanat least, at most less thancontrasted with more thanat least, at most Each of these is a subtly different claim: is true of two or any greater number, whereas requires three persons or more. Likewise, refers to zero, one, or two; to zero or one. (Of course, when the context allows numbers other than non-negative integers, me'i re can be any number less than 2, and likewise with the other cases.) The exact quantifier,
exactly 2, neither more nor less is just re. Note that su'ore is the exact Lojban equivalent of English plurals.
za'uwith elided number me'iwith elided number su'owith elided number su'ewith elided number If no number follows one of these cmavo, pa is understood: therefore,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi catlu su'o prenu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I look-at at-least [one] person

section.para: is a meaningful claim.

inexact portions with bounds Like the numbers in , all of these cmavo may be preceded by pi to make the corresponding quantifiers for part of a whole. For example, pisu'o means
at least some part of. The quantifiers ro, su'o, piro, and pisu'o are particularly important in Lojban, as they are implicitly used in the descriptions introduced by the cmavo of selma'o LA and LE, as explained in
. Descriptions in general are outside the scope of this chapter.

section.title: Non-decimal and compound bases
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

radixdecimal (see also base) In normal contexts, Lojban assumes that all numbers are expressed in the decimal (base 10) system. However, other bases are possible, and may be appropriate in particular circumstances.
octal systemspecifying numbers in (see also base) binary systemspecifying numbers in (see also base) basespecifying To specify a number in a particular base, the VUhU operator ju'u is suitable:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li pa no pa no ju'u re du li pa no
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number 1010 base 2 equals the-number 10.

section.para: basechanging permanently baseassumed Here, the final pa no is assumed to be base 10, as usual; so is the base specification. (The base may also be changed permanently by a metalinguistic specification; no standard way of doing so has as yet been worked out.)

hexadecimal systemspecifying numbers in (see also base) digitsrationale for having 16 Lojban has digits for representing bases up to 16, because 16 is a base often used in computer applications. In English, it is customary to use the letters A-F as the base 16 digits equivalent to the numbers ten through fifteen. In Lojban, this ambiguity is avoided:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li daufeigai ju'u paxa du li rezevobi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number ABC base 16 equals the-number 2748.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li jaureivai ju'u paxa du li cimuxaze
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number DEF base 16 equals the-number 3567.

section.para: digits beyond 9word pattern Note the pattern in the cmavo: the diphthongs au, ei, ai are used twice in the same order. The digits for A to D use consonants different from those used in the decimal digit cmavo; E and F unfortunately overlap 2 and 4 – there was simply not enough available cmavo space to make a full differentiation possible. The cmavo are also in alphabetical order.

decimal pointin bases other than 10 base pointin bases other than 10 The base point
pi is used in non-decimal bases just as in base 10:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li vai pi bi ju'u paxa du li pamu pi mu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number F.8 base 16 equals the-number 15.5.

section.para: basenon-constant ju'ugrammar of Since ju'u is an operator of selma'o VUhU, it is grammatical to use any operand as the left argument. Semantically, however, it is undefined to use anything but a numeral string on the left. The reason for making ju'u an operator is to allow reference to a base which is not a constant.

compound basedefinition compound baseseparator for base varying for each digitseparator for There are some numerical values that require a base that varies from digit to digit. For example, times represented in hours, minutes, and seconds have, in effect, three
digits: the first is base 24, the second and third are base 60. To express such numbers, the compound base separator
pi'e is used:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ci pi'e rere pi'e vono

section.para: compound baseexpressing digits in Each digit sequence separated by instances of pi'e is expressed in decimal notation, but the number as a whole is not decimal and can only be added and subtracted by special rules:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ci pi'e rere pi'e vono su'i pi'e ci pi'e cici du li ci pi'e rexa pi'e paci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number 3:22:40 plus :3:33 equals the-number 3:26:13.

section.para: Of course, only context tells you that the first part of the numbers in and is hours, the second minutes, and the third seconds.

base greater than 16expressing numbers in Mayan mathematicsas a system with base larger than 16 The same mechanism using pi'e can be used to express numbers which have a base larger than 16. For example, base-20 Mayan mathematics might use digits from
no to paso, each separated by pi'e:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li pa pi'e re pi'e ci ju'u reno du li vovoci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-number 1;2;3 base 20 equals the-number 443

section.para: base greater than 16two digits contrasted with compound single-digits base greater than 16compound single-digits contrasted with two digits Carefully note the difference between:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pano ju'u reno
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-digit-10 base 20

section.para: which is equal to ten, and:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pa pi'e no ju'u reno
interlinear-gloss.gloss: 1;0 base 20

section.para: which is equal to twenty.
large-base decimal fractionexpressing Both pi and pi'e can be used to express large-base fractions:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li pa pi'e vo pi ze ju'u reno du li re vo pi ci mu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number 1;4.7 base 20 equals the-number 24.35.

section.para: basevague pi'e is also used where the base of each digit is vague, as in the numbering of the examples in this chapter:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: dei jufra panopi'epapamoi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: This-utterance is-a-sentence-type-of 10;11th-thing.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: This is Sentence 10.11.

section.title: Special mekso selbri
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

numerical selbrispecial Lojban possesses a special category of selbri which are based on mekso. The simplest kind of such selbri are made by suffixing a member of selma'o MOI to a number. There are five members of MOI, each of which serves to create number-based selbri with specific place structures.
cardinal selbridefinition cardinal selbriplace structure The cmavo mei creates cardinal selbri. The basic place structure is:

definition.content: x1 is a mass formed from the set x2 of n members, one or more of which is/are x3

section.para: massexpressing relation with individuals forming massexpressing relation with set forming individualsexpressing relation with mass formed individualsexpressing relation with set formed setexpressing relation with individuals forming set setexpressing relation with mass formed from set A cardinal selbri interrelates a set with a given number of members, the mass formed from that set, and the individuals which make the set up. The mass argument is placed first as a matter of convenience, not logical necessity.
Some examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: lei mi ratcu cu cimei
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Those-I-describe-as-the-mass-of my rats are-a-threesome.
My rats are three.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I have three rats.

section.para: Here, the mass of my rats is said to have three components; that is, I have three rats.
Another example, with one element this time:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi poi pamei cu cusku dei
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I who am-an-individual express this-sentence.

section.para: In , mi refers to a mass, the mass consisting of me. Personal pronouns are vague between masses, sets, and individuals.
However, when the number expressed before -mei is an objective indefinite number of the kind explained in , a slightly different place structure is required:

indexterm.secondary: place structure formed for objective indefinites

definition.content: x1 is a mass formed from a set x2 of n members, one or more of which is/are x3, measured relative to the set x4.

section.para: An example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: lei ratcu poi zvati le panka cu so'umei lo'i ratcu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-mass-of rats which are-in the park are a-fewsome with-respect-to the-set-of rats.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The rats in the park are a small number of all the rats there are.

section.para:
lo'i
lo'iwith elided quantifiers In , the x2 and x3 places are vacant, and the x4 place is filled by lo'i ratcu, which (because no quantifiers are explicitly given) means the whole of the set of all those things which are rats, or simply the set of all rats.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le'i ratcu poi zvati le panka cu se so'imei
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-set-of rats which-are in the park is-a manysome.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: There are many rats in the park.

section.para: In , the conversion cmavo se swaps the x1 and the x2 places, so that the new x1 is the set. The x4 set is unspecified, so the implication is that the rats are many with respect to some unspecified comparison set.
More explanations about the interrelationship of sets, masses, and individuals can be found in .
ordinal selbridefinition ordinal selbriplace structure The cmavo moi creates ordinal selbri. The place structure is:

definition.content: x1 is the (n)th member of set x2 when ordered by rule x3

section.para: Some examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti pamoi le'i mi ratcu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: This-one is the first-of the rats associated-with me.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: This is my first rat.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta romoi le'i mi ratcu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-the-allth-of the rats associated-with me.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is my last rat.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi raumoi le velskina porsi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-enough-th-in the movie-audience sequence
I am enough-th in the movie line.

section.para: means, in the appropriate context, that my position in line is sufficiently far to the front that I will get a seat for the movie.
portion selbriplace structure portion selbridefinition The cmavo si'e creates portion selbri. The place structure is:

definition.content: x1 is an (n)th portion of mass x2

section.para: Some examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: levi sanmi cu fi'ucisi'e lei mi djedi cidja
interlinear-gloss.gloss: This-here meal is-a-slash-three-portion-of my day-food.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: This meal is one-third of my daily food.

section.para: probability selbriplace structure probability selbridefinition one-third of food The cmavo cu'o creates probability selbri. The place structure is:

definition.content: event x1 has probability (n) of occurring under conditions x2

section.para: probability selbrivalues The number must be between 0 and 1 inclusive. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nu lo sicni cu sedja'o cu pimucu'o
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The event of a coin being a head-displayer has probability .5.

section.para: scale selbriplace structure scale selbridefinition The cmavo va'e creates a scale selbri. The place structure is:

definition.content: x1 is at scale position (n) on the scale x2

section.para:
unreduced fractionsuse in granular scales scalegranular contrasted with continuous If the scale is granular rather than continuous, a form like
cifi'uxa (3/6) may be used; in this case, 3/6 is not the same as 1/2, because the third position on a scale of six positions is not the same as the first position on a scale of two positions. Here is an example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le vi rozgu cu sofi'upanova'e xunre
interlinear-gloss.gloss: This rose is 9/10-scale red.
This rose is 9 out of 10 on the scale of redness.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: This rose is very red.

section.para:
scale selbriplace structure effect from subjective numbers probability selbriplace structure effect from subjective numbers portion selbriplace structure effect from subjective numbers ordinal selbriplace structure effect from subjective numbers cardinal selbriplace structure effect from subjective numbers subjective numberseffect on place structure for scale selbri subjective numberseffect on place structure for probability selbri subjective numberseffect on place structure for portion selbri subjective numberseffect on place structure for ordinal selbri subjective numberseffect on place structure for cardinal selbri When the quantifier preceding any MOI cmavo includes the subjective numbers rau,
du'e, or
mo'a (enough, too many, too few) then an additional place is added for
by standard. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: lei ratcu poi zvati le panka cu du'emei fo mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-mass-of rats which-are in the park are too-many by-standard me.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: There are too many rats in the park for me.

section.para:
subjective numbersrationale for effect on place structure too many ratsexample The extra place (which for -mei is the x4 place labeled by fo) is provided rather than using a BAI tag such as ma'i because a specification of the standard for judgment is essential to the meaning of subjective words like
enough.

subjective numbersspecifying standard for standard for subjective numbersspecifying This place is not normally explicit when using one of the subjective numbers directly as a number. Therefore, du'e ratcu means
too many rats without specifying any standard.
lerfu stringswith numerical selbri numerical selbrispecialwith lerfu strings It is also grammatical to substitute a lerfu string for a number:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ny.moi le'i mi ratcu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-nth-of the-set-of my rats.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is my nth rat.

section.para: numerical selbrirestriction on numbers used for numerical selbrigrammar More complex mekso cannot be placed directly in front of MOI, due to the resulting grammatical ambiguities. Instead, a somewhat artificial form of expression is required.

numerical selbrialternative to compensate for restriction on numbers "me"effect of MOI on numerical selbricomplex numerical selbriuse of "me" with The cmavo me (of selma'o ME) has the function of making a sumti into a selbri. A whole me construction can have a member of MOI added to the end to create a complex mekso selbri:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta me li ny. su'i pa me'u moi le'i mi ratcu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is the-number n plus one-th-of the-set-of my rats.
That is my (n+1)-th rat.

section.para: Here the mekso ny. su'i pa is made into a sumti (with li) and then changed into a mekso selbri with me and me'u moi. The elidable terminator me'u is required here in order to keep the pa and the moi separate; otherwise, the parser will combine them into the compound pamoi and reject the sentence as ungrammatical.
numerical selbribased on non-numerical sumti It is perfectly possible to use non-numerical sumti after me and before a member of MOI, producing strange results indeed:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nu mi nolraitru cu me le'e snime bolci be vi la xel. cu'o
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The event-of me being-a-nobly-superlative-ruler has-the-stereotypical snow type-of-ball at Hell probability.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I have a snowball's chance in Hell of being king.

section.para: boieffect on elidability of me'u MOI selma'ouse of boi before PA selma'oexception on use of boi with MOI boiexception before MOI Note: the elidable terminator boi is not used between a number and a member of MOI. As a result, the me'u in could also be replaced by a boi, which would serve the same function of preventing the pa and moi from joining into a compound.

section.title: Number questions
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li re su'i re du li xo
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number 2 plus 2 equals the-number what?
interlinear-gloss.natlang: What is 2 + 2?

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le xomoi prenu cu darxi do
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The what-number-th person hit you?
Which person [as in a police lineup] hit you?

section.para: questionsdigit digit questions police lineup xo can also be combined with other digits to ask questions whose answers are already partly specified. This ability could be very useful in writing tests of elementary arithmetical knowledge:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li remu pi'i xa du li paxono
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number 25 times 6 equals the-number 1?0

section.para: number questionsanswers to numbersas grammatically complete utterances to which the correct reply would be mu, or 5. The ability to utter bare numbers as grammatical Lojban sentences is primarily intended for giving answers to xo questions. (Another use, obviously, is for counting off physical objects one by one.)

section.title: Subscripts
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

subscriptsexternal grammar of Subscripting is a general Lojban feature, not used only in mekso; there are many things that can logically be subscripted, and grammatically a subscript is a free modifier, usable almost anywhere. In particular, of course, mekso variables (lerfu strings) can be subscripted:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li xy.boixici du li xy.boixipa su'i xy.boixire
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number x-sub-3 equals the-number x-sub-1 plus x-sub-2.

section.para: subscriptsinternal grammar of Subscripts always begin with the flag xi (of selma'o XI). xi may be followed by a number, a lerfu string, or a general mekso expression in parentheses:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: xy.boixino
xy.boixiny.
xy.boixi vei ny. su'i pa [ve'o]

section.para: free modifierseffects on elidability of terminators subscriptseffects on elidability of terminators subscripts on lerfu wordseffect on elidability of boi Note that subscripts attached directly to lerfu words (variables) generally need a boi terminating the variable. Free modifiers, of which subscripts are one variety, generally require the explicit presence of an otherwise elidable terminator.

superscripts subscriptsbefore main expression There is no standard way of handling superscripts (other than those used as exponents) or for subscripts or superscripts that come before the main expression. If necessary, further cmavo could be assigned to selma'o XI for these purposes.

sub-subscripts subscriptsmultiple as sub-subscript subscriptsterminator for The elidable terminator for a subscript is that for a general number or lerfu string, namely boi. By convention, a subscript following another subscript is taken to be a sub-subscript:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: xy.boi xi by.boi xi vo

section.para: See for the standard method of specifying multiple subscripts on a single object.
More information on the uses of subscripts may be found in .

section.title: Infix operators revisited
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

The infix operators presented so far have always had exactly two operands, and for more or fewer operands forethought notation has been required. However, it is possible to use an operator in infix style even though it has more or fewer than two operands, through the use of a pair of tricks: the null operand
tu'o and the null operator
ge'a. The first is suitable when there are too few operands, the second when there are too many. For example, suppose we wanted to express the numerical negation operator
va'a in infix form. We would use:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li tu'o va'a ny. du li no vu'u ny.
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number (null) additive-inverse n equals the-number zero minus n.

section.para:
operandstoo few for infix operation null operandfor infix operations with too few operands tu'ofor infix operations with too few operands The tu'o fulfills the grammatical requirement for a left operand for the infix use of
va'a, even though semantically none is needed or wanted.

exponential notationwith gei scientific notationwith gei geias a binary operator Finding a suitable example of ge'a requires exhibiting a ternary operator, and ternary operators are not common. The operator gei, however, has both a binary and a ternary use. As a binary operator, it provides a terse representation of scientific (also called exponential) notation. The first operand of gei is the exponent, and the second operand is the mantissa or fraction:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li cinonoki'oki'o du li bi gei ci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number three-zero-zero-comma-comma equals the-number eight scientific three.

section.para: geirationale for order of places scientific notationrationale for order of places Why are the arguments to gei in reverse order from the conventional symbolic notation? So that gei can be used in forethought to allow easy specification of a large (or small) imprecise number:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: gei reno
interlinear-gloss.gloss: (scientific) two-zero

section.para: floating point numbersexpressing exponential notationwith base other than 10 geias a ternary operator operandstoo many for infix operation null operatorfor infix operations with too many operands ge'afor infix operations with too many operands Note, however, that although 10 is far and away the most common exponent base, it is not the only possible one. The third operand of gei, therefore, is the base, with 10 as the default value. Most computers internally store so-called floating-point numbers using 2 as the exponent base. (This has nothing to do with the fact that computers also represent all integers in base 2; the IBM 360 series used an exponent base of 16 for floating point, although each component of the number was expressed in base 2.) Here is a computer floating-point number with a value of 40:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: papano bi'eju'u re gei pipanopano bi'eju'u re ge'a re
interlinear-gloss.gloss: (one-one-zero base 2) scientific (point-one-zero-one-zero base 2) with-base 2

section.title: Vectors and matrices
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

matrixdefinition vectordefinition A mathematical vector is a list of numbers, and a mathematical matrix is a table of numbers. Lojban considers matrices to be built up out of vectors, which are in turn built up out of operands.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li jo'i paboi reboi te'u su'i jo'i ciboi voboi du li jo'i voboi xaboi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number array (one, two) plus array (three, four) equals the-number array (four, six).

section.para:
matrixwith ge'a for more than 2 rows/columns matrixas combination of vectors matrix column operator matrix row operator Vectors can be combined into matrices using either pi'a, the matrix row operator, or
sa'i, the matrix column operator. The first combines vectors representing rows of the matrix, and the second combines vectors representing columns of the matrix. Both of them allow any number of arguments: additional arguments are tacked on with the null operator
ge'a.
Therefore, the magic square matrix
can be represented either as:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: jo'i biboi paboi xa pi'a jo'i ciboi muboi ze ge'a jo'i voboi soboi re
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-vector (8 1 6) matrix-row the-vector (3 5 7), the-vector (4 9 2)

section.para: or as

interlinear-gloss.jbo: jo'i biboi ciboi vo sa'i jo'i paboi muboi so ge'a jo'i xaboi zeboi re
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-vector (8 3 4) matrix-column the-vector (1 5 9), the-vector (6 7 2)

section.para: matricesuse of parentheses with vectorsuse of parentheses with matricesuse as operands vectorsuse as operands inner product outer product The regular mekso operators can be applied to vectors and to matrices, since grammatically both of these are expressions. It is usually necessary to parenthesize matrices when used with operators in order to avoid incorrect groupings. There are no VUhU operators for the matrix operators of inner or outer products, but appropriate operators can be created using a suitable symbolic lerfu word or string prefixed by ma'o.

xi subscriptsto form matrices of more than 2 dimensions matrixwith more than 2 dimensions Matrices of more than two dimensions can be built up using either pi'a or
sa'i with an appropriate subscript numbering the dimension. When subscripted, there is no difference between
pi'a and
sa'i.

section.title: Reverse Polish notation
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

RPas abbreviation for reverse Polish notation So far, the Lojban notational conventions have mapped fairly familiar kinds of mathematical discourse. The use of forethought operators may have seemed odd when applied to +, but when applied to f they appear as the usual functional notation. Now comes a sharp break. Reverse Polish (RP) notation represents something completely different; even mathematicians don't use it much. (The only common uses of RP, in fact, are in some kinds of calculators and in the implementation of some programming languages.)

reverse Polish notationterminator reverse Polish notationmarker reverse Polish notationuse of parentheses in reverse Polish notationdefinition In RP notation, the operator follows the operands. (Polish notation, where the operator precedes its operands, is another name for forethought mekso of the kind explained in .) The number of operands per operator is always fixed. No parentheses are required or permitted. In Lojban, RP notation is always explicitly marked by a fu'a at the beginning of the expression; there is no terminator. Here is a simple example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li fu'a reboi ci su'i du li mu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-number (RP!) two, three, plus equals the-number five.

section.para: The operands are re and ci; the operator is su'i.
Here is a more complex example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li fu'a reboi ci pi'i voboi mu pi'i su'i du li rexa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-number (RP!) (two, three, times), (four, five, times), plus equals the-number two-six

section.para: Here the operands of the first pi'i are re and ci; the operands of the second pi'i are vo and mu (with boi inserted where needed), and the operands of the su'i are reboi ci pi'i, or 6, and voboi mu pi'i, or 20. As you can see, it is easy to get lost in the world of reverse Polish notation; on the other hand, it is especially easy for a mechanical listener (who has a deep mental stack and doesn't get lost) to comprehend.

reverse Polish notationparentheses in operands of reverse Polish notationoperands of The operands of an RP operator can be any legal mekso operand, including parenthesized mekso that can contain any valid syntax, whether more RP or something more conventional.

reverse Polish notationwith too many operands reverse Polish notationwith too few operands reverse Polish notationnumber of operands In Lojban, RP operators are always parsed with exactly two operands. What about operators which require only one operand, or more than two operands? The null operand
tu'o and the null operator
ge'a provide a simple solution. A one-operand operator like va'a always appears in a reverse Polish context as tu'o va'a. The
tu'o provides the second operand, which is semantically ignored but grammatically necessary. Likewise, the three-operand version of
gei appears in reverse Polish as ge'a gei, where the
ge'a effectively merges the 2nd and 3rd operands into a single operand. Here are some examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li fu'a ciboi muboi vu'u du li fu'a reboi tu'o va'a
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number (RP!) (three, five, minus) equals the-number (RP!) two, null, negative-of.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li cinoki'oki'o du li fu'a biboi ciboi panoboi ge'a gei
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number 30-comma-comma equals the-number (RP!) 8, (3, 10, null-op), exponential-notation.

section.title: Logical and non-logical connectives within mekso
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

GA selma'o A selma'o afterthought connectionof operators afterthought connectionof operands forethought connectionof operators forethought connectionof operands operator connectionforethought operator connectionafterthought operand connectionforethought operand connectionafterthought As befits a logical language, Lojban has extensive provision for logical connectives within both operators and operands. Full details on logical and non-logical connectives are provided in
. Operands are connected in afterthought with selma'o A and in forethought with selma'o GA, just like sumti. Operators are connected in afterthought with selma'o JA and in forethought with selma'o GUhA, just like tanru components. This parallelism is no accident.

BO selma'o connection of operatorsgrouping connection of operandsgrouping In addition, A+BO and A+KE constructs are allowed for grouping logically connected operands, and ke…ke'e is allowed for grouping logically connected operators, although there are no analogues of tanru among the operators.
Despite the large number of rules required to support this feature, it is of relatively minor importance in the mekso scheme of things. exhibits afterthought logical connection between operands:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: vei ci .a vo ve'o prenu cu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: ( Three or four ) people go-to the market.

section.para: is equivalent in meaning, but uses forethought connection:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: vei ga ci gi vo ve'o prenu cu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: ( Either 3 or 4 ) people go-to the market.

section.para: parenthesesfor complex mekso used as quantifier meksocomplex used as quantifier Note that the mekso here are being used as quantifiers. Lojban requires that any mekso other than a simple number be enclosed in parentheses when used as a quantifier. This rule prevents ambiguities that do not exist when using li.

lo'oeffect of logical connective on elidability of logical connectioneffect on elidability of lo'o literminator for By the way, li has an elidable terminator, lo'o, which is needed when a
li sumti is followed by a logical connective that could seem to be within the mekso. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li re su'i re du li vo lo'o .onai lo nalseldjuno namcu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number two plus two equals the-number four or else a non-known number.

section.para:
Omitting the lo'o would cause the parser to assume that another operand followed the
.onai and reject lo as an invalid operand.
Simple examples of logical connection between operators are hard to come by. A contrived example is:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li re su'i je pi'i re du li vo
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number two plus and times two equals the-number four.

section.para: The forethought-connection form of is:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li re ge su'i gi pi'i re du li vo
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-number two both plus and times two equals the-number four.

section.para: Here is a classic example of operand logical connection:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: go li .abu bi'epi'i vei xy. te'a re ve'o su'i by. bi'epi'i xy. su'i cy. du li no gi li xy. du li vei va'a by. ku'e su'i ja vu'u fe'a vei by. bi'ete'a re vu'u vo bi'epi'i .abu bi'epi'i cy. ve'o [ku'e] ve'o fe'i re bi'epi'i .abu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: If-and-only-if the-number a-times-(x power two ) plus b-times- x plus c equals the-number zero then the-number x equals the-number [ the-negation-of( b ) plus or minus the-root-of (b-power-2 minus four-times- a-times- c ) ] divided-by two-times- a.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Iff ax 2 + bx + c = 0, then x = -b Â± â (b 2 â 4ac) 2a

section.para:
infix notation mixed with Polishexample Polish notation mixed with infixexample infix notation mixed with Polish Polish notation mixed with infix Note the mixture of styles in : the negation of b and the square root are represented by forethought and most of the operator precedence by prefixed
bi'e, but explicit parentheses had to be added to group the numerator properly. In addition, the square root parentheses cannot be removed here in favor of simple
fe'a and ku'e bracketing, because infix operators are present in the operand. Getting to parse perfectly using the current parser took several tries: a more relaxed style would dispense with most of the bi'e cmavo and just let the standard precedence rules be understood.

JOI selma'o non-logical connectionof operators non-logical connectionof operands Non-logical connection with JOI and BIhI is also permitted between operands and between operators. One use for this construct is to connect operands with bi'o to create intervals:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li no ga'o bi'o ke'i pa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-number zero (inclusive) from-to (exclusive) one
interlinear-gloss.natlang: the numbers from zero to one, including zero but not including one

section.para: Intervals defined by a midpoint and range rather than beginning and end points can be expressed by mi'i:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li pimu ga'o mi'i ke'i pimu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-number 0.5 Â± 0.5

section.para: closed intervalexpressed with mi'i open intervalexpressed with mi'i which expresses the same interval as . Note that the ga'o and ke'i still refer to the endpoints, although these are now implied rather than expressed. Another way of expressing the same thing:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li pimu su'i ni'upimu bi'o ma'upimu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-number 0.5 plus [-0.5 from-to +0.5]

section.para: connection of operandsprecedence over operator Here we have the sum of a number and an interval, which produces another interval centered on the number. As shows, non-logical (or logical) connection of operands has higher precedence than any mekso operator.
subscriptsmultiple for same base word compound subscript You can also combine two operands with ce'o, the sequence connective of selma'o JOI, to make a compound subscript:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: xy. xi vei by. ce'o dy. [ve'o]
interlinear-gloss.gloss: x sub ( b sequence d)

section.title: Using Lojban resources within mekso
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

mo'eterminator for ni'eterminator for na'uterminator for One of the mekso design goals requires the ability to make use of Lojban's vocabulary resources within mekso to extend the built-in cmavo for operands and operators. There are three relevant constructs: all three share the elidable terminator te'u (which is also used to terminate vectors marked with jo'i)

operator derived from selbrieffect of selbri place structure on selbri place structureeffect on operator formed by conversion of selbri into operator operatorconverting selbri into selbriconverting into an operator The cmavo na'u makes a selbri into an operator. In general, the first place of the selbri specifies the result of the operator, and the other unfilled places specify the operands:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li na'u tanjo te'u vei pai fe'i re [ve'o] du li ci'i
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number the-operator tangent (Ï / 2 ) = the-number infinity.

section.para: tanjo is the gismu for x1 is the tangent of x2, and the na'u here makes it into an operator which is then used in forethought

formulaeexpressing based on pure dimensions conversion of selbri into operand operandconverting selbri into selbriconverting into an operand The cmavo ni'e makes a selbri into an operand. The x1 place of the selbri generally represents a number, and therefore is often a
ni abstraction, since ni abstractions represent numbers. The ni'e makes that number available as a mekso operand. A common application is to make equations relating pure dimensions:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ni'e ni clani [te'u] pi'i ni'e ni ganra [te'u] pi'i ni'e ni condi te'u du li ni'e ni canlu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number quantity-of length times quantity-of width times quantity-of depth equals the-number quantity-of volume.
interlinear-gloss.math: Length Ã Width Ã Depth = Volume

section.para:
dimensioned numbersexpressing conversion of sumti into operand operandconverting sumti into sumticonverting into an operand The cmavo mo'e operates similarly to
ni'e, but makes a sumti (rather than a selbri) into an operand. This construction is useful in stating equations involving dimensioned numbers:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li mo'e re ratcu su'i mo'e re ractu du li mo'e vo danlu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number two rats plus two rabbits equals the-number four animals.

section.para:
folk quantifiersexpressing Another use is in constructing Lojbanic versions of so-called folk quantifiers, such as
a pride of lions:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi viska vei mo'e lo'e lanzu ve'o cinfo
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I see ( the-typical family )-number-of lions.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I see a pride of lions.

section.title: Other uses of mekso
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:
So far we have seen mekso used as sumti (with li), as quantifiers (often parenthesized), and in MOI and ME-MOI selbri. There are a few other minor uses of mekso within Lojban.

mathematical expressionreferring to licontrasted with me'o me'ocontrasted with li The cmavo me'o has the same grammatical use as li but slightly different semantics. li means the number which is the value of the mekso ..., whereas me'o just means the mekso ... So it is true that:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li re su'i re du li vo
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number two plus two equals the-number four.

section.para: but false that:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: me'o re su'i re du me'o vo
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-mekso two plus two equals the-mekso four.

section.para: me'orelation to li compared with la/zo relation lirelation to me'o compared with la/zo relation since the expressions 2 + 2 and 4 are not the same. The relationship between li and me'o is related to that between la djan., the person named John, and zo .djan., the name John

selbriplace structure of converted operator conversion of operator into selbri operatorconverting into selbri selbriconverting operator into The cmavo nu'a is the inverse of na'u, and allows a mekso operator to be used as a normal selbri, with the place structure:

definition.content: x1 is the result of applying (operator) to x2, x3, ...

section.para: for as many places as may be required. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ni'umu cu nu'a va'a li ma'umu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number -5 is-the-negation-of the-number +5.

section.para: uses nu'a to make the operator va'a into a two-place bridi

nu'ause in answering operator questions na'uuse in asking operator questions answersto operator questions questionsoperator Used together, nu'a and na'u make it possible to ask questions about mekso operators, even though there is no specific cmavo for an operator question, nor is it grammatical to utter an operator in isolation. Consider , to which is one correct answer:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li re na'u mo re du li vo
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number two what-operator? two equals the-number four.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: nu'a su'i
interlinear-gloss.natlang: plus

section.para: In , na'u mo is an operator question, because mo is the selbri question cmavo and na'u makes the selbri into an operator. makes the true answer su'i into a selbri (which is a legal utterance) with the inverse cmavo nu'a. Mechanically speaking, inserting into produces:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li re na'u nu'a su'i re du li vo
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number two (the-operator the-selbri plus) two equals the-number four.

section.para: where the na'u nu'a cancels out, leaving a truthful bridi

digit stringdefinition of section numbering textsub-division numbering with -mai Numerical free modifiers, corresponding to English
firstly,
secondly, and so on, can be created by suffixing a member of selma'o MAI to a digit string or a lerfu string. (Digit strings are compound cmavo beginning with a cmavo of selma'o PA, and containing only cmavo of PA or BY; lerfu strings begin with a cmavo of selma'o BY, and likewise contain only PA or BY cmavo.) Here are some examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pamai
interlinear-gloss.natlang: firstly

interlinear-gloss.jbo: remai
interlinear-gloss.natlang: secondly

interlinear-gloss.jbo: romai
interlinear-gloss.gloss: all-ly
interlinear-gloss.natlang: lastly

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ny.mai
interlinear-gloss.natlang: nth-ly

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pasomo'o
interlinear-gloss.natlang: nineteenthly (higher order)

section.para: chapter numbering mo'ocontrasted with mai maicontrasted with mo'o textdivision numbering with -mai The difference between mai and mo'o is that mo'o enumerates larger subdivisions of a text. Each mo'o subdivision can then be divided into pieces and internally numbered with mai. If this chapter were translated into Lojban, each section would be numbered with mo'o. (See for more on these words.)

tensenumerical A numerical tense can be created by suffixing a digit string with
roi. This usage generates tenses corresponding to English
once, twice, and so on. This topic belongs to a detailed discussion of Lojban tenses, and is explained further in .

numerical tenseseffect on use of boi boiexception before ROI boiexception before MAI MAI selma'oexception on use of boi before ROI selma'oexception on use of boi before Note: the elidable terminator boi is not used between a number and a member of MAI or ROI.

section.title: Explicit operator precedence
section.para: As mentioned earlier, Lojban does provide a way for the precedences of operators to be explicitly declared, although current parsers do not understand these declarations.

The declaration is made in the form of a metalinguistic comment using
ti'o, a member of selma'o SEI.
sei, the other member of SEI, is used to insert metalinguistic comments on a bridi which give information about the discourse which the bridi comprises. The format of a ti'o declaration has not been formally established, but presumably would take the form of mentioning a mekso operator and then giving it either an absolute numerical precedence on some pre-established scale, or else specifying relative precedences between new operators and existing operators.

operator precedenceplans for future In future, we hope to create an improved machine parser that can understand declarations of the precedences of simple operators belonging to selma'o VUhU. Originally, all operators would have the same precedence. Declarations would have the effect of raising the specified cmavo of VUhU to higher precedence levels. Complex operators formed with na'u, ni'e, or
ma'o would remain at the standard low precedence; declarations with respect to them are for future implementation efforts. It is probable that such a parser would have a set of commonly assumed precedences built into it (selectable by a special ti'o declaration) that would match mathematical intuition: times higher than plus, and so on.

section.title: Miscellany
section.para: A few other points:
seuse with operators conversionof operator places se can be used to convert an operator as if it were a selbri, so that its arguments are exchanged. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ci se vu'u vo du li pa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number three (inverse) minus four equals the-number one.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: 3 subtracted from 4 equals 1.

section.para: The other converters of selma'o SE can also be used on operators with more than two operands, and they can be compounded to create (probably unintelligible) operators as needed.

NAhE selma'o negationof operator Members of selma'o NAhE are also legal on an operator to produce a scalar negation of it. The implication is that some other operator would apply to make the bridi true:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ci na'e su'i vo du li pare
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number 3 non-plus 4 equals the-number 12.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li ci to'e vu'u re du li mu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number 3 opposite-of-minus 2 equals the-number 5.

section.para: The sense in which plus is the opposite of minus is not a mathematical but rather a linguistic one; negated operators are defined only loosely.

negationof operand symbolfor operand referentof operand la'e and lu'e can be used on operands with the usual semantics to get the referent of or a symbol for an operand. Likewise, a member of selma'o NAhE followed by bo serves to scalar-negate an operand, implying that some other operand would make the bridi true:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li re su'i re du li na'ebo mu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The-number 2 plus 2 equals the-number non-5.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: 2 + 2 = something other than 5.

section.para: digitsnames from digitsrafsi for The digits 0-9 have rafsi, and therefore can be used in making lujvo. Additionally, all the rafsi have CVC form and can stand alone or together as names:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la zel. poi gunta la tebes. pu nanmu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Those-named Seven who attack that-named Thebes [past] are-men.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The Seven Against Thebes were men.

section.para: Of course, there is no guarantee that the name zel. is connected with the number rafsi: an alternative which cannot be misconstrued is:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la zemei poi gunta la tebes. pu nanmu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Those-named-the Sevensome who attack Thebes [past] are-men.

section.para:
rafsiconventional meaning for frinu PA selma'omembers with rafsi Certain other members of PA also have assigned rafsi: so'a,
so'e,
so'i,
so'o,
so'u,
da'a, ro, su'e,
su'o, pi, and ce'i. Furthermore, although the cmavo
fi'u does not have a rafsi as such, it is closely related to the gismu
frinu, meaning fraction; therefore, in a context of numeric rafsi, you can use any of the rafsi for frinu to indicate a fraction slash.

rafsiconventional meaning for cu'o A similar convention is used for the cmavo cu'o of selma'o MOI, which is closely related to
cunso (probability); use a rafsi for cunso in order to create lujvo based on cu'o. The cmavo
mei and moi of MOI have their own rafsi, two each in fact: mem/ mei and mom/ moi respectively.

operandconverting from operator operatorconverting into operand conversion of operator into operand algebra of functionsoperator and operand distinction in lambda calculusoperator and operand distinction in The grammar of mekso as described so far imposes a rigid distinction between operators and operands. Some flavors of mathematics (lambda calculus, algebra of functions) blur this distinction, and Lojban must have a method of doing the same. An operator can be changed into an operand with
ni'enu'a, which transforms the operator into a matching selbri and then the selbri into an operand.

operatorconverting from operand operandconverting into operator conversion of operand into operator To change an operand into an operator, we use the cmavo ma'o, already introduced as a means of changing a lerfu string such as fy. into an operator. In fact, ma'o can be followed by any mekso operand, using the elidable terminator te'u if necessary.

ma'opotential ambiguity caveat There is a potential semantic ambiguity in ma'o fy. [te'u] if fy. is already in use as a variable: it comes to mean the function whose value is always f. However, mathematicians do not normally use the same lerfu words or strings as both functions and variables, so this case should not arise in practice.

section.title: Four score and seven: a mekso problem
section.para:
meksoand literary translation Abraham Lincoln's Gettysburg Address begins with the words
Four score and seven years ago. This section exhibits several different ways of saying the number
four score and seven. (A score, for those not familiar with the term, is 20; it is analogous to a dozen for 12.) The trivial way:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li bize
interlinear-gloss.gloss: eight seven

section.para: is mathematically correct, but sacrifices the spirit of the English words, which are intended to be complex and formal.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li vo pi'i reno su'i ze
interlinear-gloss.gloss: four times twenty plus seven

section.para: scoreas 20-year span is also mathematically correct, but still misses something. Score is not a word for 20 in the same way that ten is a word for 10: it contains the implication of 20 objects. The original may be taken as short for Four score years and seven years ago. Thinking of a score as a twentysome rather than as 20 leads to:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li mo'e voboi renomei te'u su'i ze
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the-number-of four twentysomes plus seven

section.para:
In , voboi renomei is a sumti signifying four things each of which are groups of twenty; the mo'e and
te'u then make this sumti into a number in order to allow it to be the operand of su'i.

base-20 arithmeticremnants of scoreas alternate base for years Another approach is to think of score as setting a representation base. There are remnants of base-20 arithmetic in some languages, notably French, in which 87 is
quatre-vingt-sept, literally four-twenties-seven. (This fact makes the Gettysburg Address hard to translate into French!) If
score is the representation base, then we have:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li vo pi'e ze ju'u reno
interlinear-gloss.gloss: four ; seven base 20

section.para: Overall, probably captures the flavor of the English best. and are too simple, and is too tricky. Nevertheless, all four examples are good Lojban. Pedagogically, these examples illustrate the richness of lojbau mekso: anything that can be said at all, can probably be said in more than one way.
